Speaker: Mr BEVIS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Can the Treasurer inform the House of the administrative arrangements required for Australian workers to receive in their pay packets the income tax cuts with immediate effect from 15 November? Has the Treasurer received advice on the effects of the tax cuts on consumer demand over the Christmas period?

Speaker: Mr DAWKINS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. He is drawing attention to the fact that, prior to the actual payment of the tax cuts into the pockets of Australian working men and women, the Taxation Office must make certain administrative arrangements with employers who can give effect to those changed rates in those pay packets. New rates ofPAYE tax instalment deductions must be prescribed. New tax instalment schedules must be printed. The tax instalment schedules must be distributed to employers, and employers will then require time to modify their payroll systems. This process cannot begin until such time as the bill has passed the parliament and received royal assent. There is then a three-week delay from that period before the effect of the tax changes can be reflected within the pay packets of Australian working men and women. It is the government's intention to ensure that those tax cuts are paid from the pay period closest to 15 November. This is because we believe it is important to have those tax cuts in the pockets of Australian taxpayers prior to the Christmas period. It is also part of providing a stimulus to the economy and a benefit to middle Australia. On the advice of the Commissioner of of Taxation, this means that the bills would have to be passed through the Senate by 21 October. Of course, any action on the part of the Liberals in delaying that passage beyond the 21st would lead to a delay in those tax cuts being reflected in the pay packets of taxpayers. One must ask: what do the Liberals have against those people who are the target beneficiaries of the tax cuts? Some Liberals even seem to oppose the very idea of providing the tax cuts, and all of them seem to be entirely nonchalant about the idea that these Tax Cuts payments should be delayed. A typical taxpaying Australian, a stenographer secretary currently on a weekly income of $520 would benefit in the course of this financial year by $159. The amount that secretary would receive before Christmas would be $32. A bus driver on $610 a week would expect to receive $55 before Christmas, a nurse would receive $91 and a motor mechanic would receive $34. Imagine how handy it would be for those people to have a benefit in the form of a tax cut so that they could make their purchases prior to Christmas. Yet it is the opposition tactic to find whatever delaying mechanism it can-whether some trumped-up legal argument, reference to a Senate committee or some other trumped-up argument-to deny these ordinary, average, working men and women in Australia the tax cuts which are due to them. The point is that the Senate and the Liberals will bear the responsibility for any delays which occur in this regard. If any of these tax cuts are not received before Christmas and not taken into account in the PAYE schedules, those taxpayers will have to wait until July next year to receive the benefit of those tax cuts by way of a refund on their tax assessment. The coalition carries a heavy responsibility for the kinds of Christmas tidings that ordinary Australians are likely to have this year. Wholesale Sales Tax

Speaker: Mr FERGUSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Given Sydney's success in winning the bid to host the year 2000 Olympics, in which most events will be held at HOJ1lebush Bay, can the minister explain to the House the federal government's role in preparing our team for the games? What benefits will flow from the games to Australian sports in general?

Speaker: Mrs KELLY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Yesterday in the House the Prime Minister congratulated all the people who had been involved in the bid for the Olympic Games, and I would like to reinforce that. Today it has been announced that the Paralympics also will be held in Sydney. I am sure that I could extend the best wishes of everyone in this House to the paralympic committee which, with the support of the Sydney 2000 bid, has put forward a successful bid. Both these bids have had the support of all levels of government. They have built on the bids from Melbourne and also from Brisbane. One of the main reasons for the success of our Olympic bid was undoubtedly international recognition of us as a successful sporting nation. We now have more world champions in more sports than ever before. This was a very high quality technical bid, based on the interests of the athletes, to provide a clean environment for them to perform at their maximum capacity. So, in the next seven years, the test for all of us-all governments, communities and sporting organisations-is to build on that success to produce not only the best and the most successful team ever but also to produce the fittest and the healthiest society. It is. essential that we realise that, though Sydney is the host city, these games are for the all Australians and for all Australian sport. We must provide an Australian team, not just a Sydney team. Our challenge is to win more gold medals than we did in Melbourne. As the host nation, we will be competing in events that we have never qualified in before. We must do well in those events. To do well, we need the support of everyone, including every honourable member in this House. Mr Nehl- Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order understanding order 145-that of relevance. The question specifically asked was: what will the federal government's contribution be to the holding of the 2000 Olympics? So far the only contribution has been blabber. Can we get some facts out of this minister?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Order! There is no point of order. The minister is entirely relevant.

Speaker: Mrs KELLY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thought that the honourable member would appreciate the congratulations of this House being extended to the Australian Paralympic Federation. What will the government be doing? First, we must have a national effort. All state governments must be involved, so I will be writing today to all my state colleagues proposing a mechanism to ensure national coordination. We will also be working with the Australian Olympic Committee, and I will be meeting with John Coates, the President of the committee, on Thursday of this week. We are currently providing about $80 million a year in sport and we have done that over the last five years, so we are building on a very strong base. But we have to work with the national sporting groups and the Olympic Committee to ensure that they have a strong foundation and that our base on which to build our elite athletes is firm. Over this year in particular we will be giving $25 million directly to Olympic sports. By the year 2000 this will total some $200 million, and one would expect funding to increase as we get closer. The government has already contributed $5 million to the Olympic bid, tnaking it one of the biggest contributors to the bid, and we have already committed $150 million to the New South Wales government to help with the development of the games facilities. The interest expected in this will be enormous, not just in the year 2000 but in the build-up, and I think all Australians will benefit from that. For example, last week we had calls from members of the Japanese Olympic Committee wanting to come to Australia to look at our facilities. So there will be a lot of interest and a lot of benefits outside of the direct benefits to sport. The centre of our activities has to be the Australian Sports Commission, the elite bodies around this nation in each of the states and the Australian Institute of Sport. However, if we are going to provide this challenge to win these gold medals, we have. to build our base in sport. We have to enhance - port­ ing participation and development in this nation, and we have to start withour school children. That will be one of our great challenges. We cannot produce top class olympic athletes while we continue this trend to get rid of sport in schools. State governments in particular have' to keep that in mind. Sport has to continue in our schools, especially in Queensland but also in every other state in this nation. We must win more gold medals at the Olympics in the year 2000, but we also need to build our base and, therefore, lead to a fitter and healthier society in the year 2000. Tax Cuts

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What is the government's assessment of the situation in South Africa? What is the government doing to assist the transition to democracy in that country? . Mr BILNEY-I thank the honourable member for his question. It comes particularly appositely from him as the Chairman of the Australian Parliamentarians Against Apartheid group in this parliament. I acknowledge the personal interest he has taken in this question over the years, including visiting that sad country. Amongst the very momentous events that have taken place in recent days-in Russia, in the Middle East and in Monaco-not the least momentous has been the passage through the parliament in South Africa of legislation on the tran-itional executive council which took place on 23 September. The result of that legislation means that for the first time representatives of all the communities in South. Africa will be able to participate in national government institutions. Of course, that is not the end of the matter. Nelson Mandela observed in his speech to the United Nations the other day that South Africa is not out of the woods yet, and that is partly because some of the political parties continue to boycott the negotiations for the democratic parliament. The government hopes that those parties will return quickly to those multilateral talks so that the proposed timing for the democratic elections in South AfricaApril 1994-can be met. We in the government are also concerned at the continuing high levels of violence in South Africa. We believe much of that is deliberately orchestratdifficult ed in order to undennine the multiparty constitutional negotiations which are currently under way. The honourable member for Throsby also asked what the Australian government is doing .to assist the process of transition to non-racial democracy in South Africa. Austnilia has supported the role of the interrlational community in observing the situation in South Africa as agreed by the United Nations Security Council in UN Security Council resolution 772 of 17 August last year. In accordance with that mandate, Australia has participated in the Commonwealth observer mission to South Africa...:....COMSA-whose aim is to work with the committee set· up under the national peace accord to try· to achieve an end to violence. The third phase of COMSA's operation began in the middle of August and, amongst other issues, it is looking at the implications of violence for the elections scheduled in April next year.. We have a direct participant in those observations, Mr Tim Glanville, a senior officer of the Australian Electoral Commission. We are also discussing with .other members of the Commonwealth possible Commonwealth involvement in observing the elections in South Africa in April 1994 and assisting with their conduct, as indeed we did in Zimbabwe in years past. On· 17 December I also announced that Australia will assist South Africa through our aid program, through modifying and redesigning our special assistance program for South Africa in order to address the new political circumstances in South Africa. That package of aid will comprise around $7 million this year, and will include the use of Australian expertise in key areas such. as the electoral process, economic policy and planning, media training, civil service and. constitutional and local government refonn. We have already let contracts through AIDAB of almost $1 million for media democratisation and television journalist training in South Africa. The black colllIhunity has suffered for many years under the oppression of apartheid and it will need all the assistance it can get from the international community through that transition from apartheid to democracy. The Australian government remains, as it has always been, committed to helping with that task. Olympic Games

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Newcastle for his question. It gives me the opportunity to reflect on the opposition's approach to policy. Following the release yesterday of some HIA numbers in relation to the activity of volume builders, which showed a slight downturn, the shadow minister, the honourable member for Forrest in his press release said: Sighs of a fall in new home sales, revealed in the HIA's latest industry survey, show a continued upswing in housing activity is far from being thing. There is a sign, some numbers are out, and imm-diately the honourable member for Forrest needs to let the Australian people know that, as he says, as a result of a lack of confidence in the budget, we are due for a downturn in housing activity. The honourable member for Forrest apparently does not know that the Government's official forecast, the IPC, predicts that there will be a decline from 161,000 starts last year to 150,000 starts in the course of this year. Effectively, in terms of the official forecast,we have some expectation of a decline. The surprising thing is that the housing industry, in a sense, is refusing to go the way of the forecast this year and high levels of activity are continuing in the housing industry. When I was in Newcastle recently my attention was drawn to the fact that the city of Newcastle in recent years has had the first increase in population in many decades. 1 was interested to inquire about some of the reasons for that increase in the population of that more mature city. 1 was told it was due in part to the innovative housing options in the city, including medium density housing, shop tops and regulatory reform to enable the industry to respond quickly to consumer Housing demand. This trend is emerging in capital cities around Australia and, indeed, reflects the Government's policy to provide greater choice for Australians and housing-choices that enable the Australian population to meet their needs and preferences-and the changing lifestyles of people. For example, at the tum of the century nearly half of the population will be over the age of 45 and only 20 per cent of household income units will consist of a traditional family, two adults and two children. Almost 50 per cent of household income units will be single people or childless couples over the age of 35. It is an extraordinary statistic to suggest that half the household units in Australia will be one or two person households and that 20 per cent of households in this country, just after the tum of the century, will have children within them. That suggests a very big demoa sure graphic change. The housing industry clearly needs to respond to that change. It is of no moment at all that the honourable member for Forrest should grab at a small s-atistic, of no long-term significance, in order to tear away in confidence, to tear away at the housing industry in this country and show no capacity at all to reflect on a long-term trend which is extremely important in housing the Australian population. The government's policy is to encourage much greater choice in housing in this country and to look to ensure that affordability, which is the strongest it has been for eight years, continues and that housing interest rates remain low. They are now at the lowest level they have been for several decades. Rather than there being some early sign of some downturn, there is one set of statistics. If we look at the overall picture that is emerging, we see that it shows the housing industry in good shape, a trend towards medium density housing and a range of housing types which at the moment are the growing edge, the cutting edge, in the housing industry in this country.  have them in boxes.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: by leave- Mr Speaker, I wish to inform the House of the outcome of my visit to the United States, the United Kingdom, Ireland, France and Monaco between 11 and 24 September. During the visit, I dealt with a number of issues which will have a profound bearing on Australia's trading interests and future prosperity, on our national identity, and on how we and others see our place in the world. These are all big questions, and it is important that we get them right. At a time of great fluidity in international affairs, we now face fundamental questions about the structure of the world trading system. The opportunity to secure a successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round is now close at hand, but the outcome is far from assured. The APEC forum, which Australia has done so much to bring forward, is now poised to develop into a valuable framework for promoting trade and investment in the Asia-Pacific region. The United States Congress will soon decide whether or not to approve the North American free trade agreement with far-reaching repercussions either way on the US trade policy stance. At this pivotal moment in the international trading environment, it is important that Australians are fully aware of the impact that decisions about future trade structures will have on our interests. Mr Speaker, at stake is nothing less than the future prosperity of our country. At stake is our capacity to provide employment for the next generation of Australians. More than ever before Australia is on its own internationally, fending for itself in a competitive and challenging international environment. papers: But we are seen internationally as a modem society with many assets to help us make our way successfully in the world. Our recent achievements in fostering a tolerant and diverse multicultural society, and in executing a series of major reforms of the Australian economy, highlight our capacity to chartge and to play an increasing role in regional and international affairs. These subjects were the main thrust of my discussions in each of the capitals I visited. Mr Speaker, I visited Washington at a time when Australia's most pressing interests coincide with much that is prominent on the American agenda. The future of the Uruguay Round, the development of APEC and the creation of NAFfAare all matters to which President Clinton, his administration and the Congress are giving high priority. It was a very useful time to be able to put Australia's view and to represent our interests on these issues. Given the enormous stakes involved, it was important to be able to discuss with the United States administration and Congress what sort of policy and institutional framework will best maintain and strengthen the highly valuable economic linkages which now operate between east Asia, Oceania and North America. So strong have these linkages between North America and the western Pacific become over the last decade that today there is a higher degree of trade integration among the f 5 members of APEC than there is among the members of the European Community, or among the three North American economies, or among the east Asian economies considered separately. While the United States market remains vitally important for most east Asian economies, I found a growing awareness in the administration and in Congress that east Asia has also become an increasingly important market for United States exports. Indeed, less than a decade ago, more than one-third of western Pacific exports went to the United States. Today, the proportion is less than quarter. But, over the same period, the proportion of US exports which go to the western Pacific has risen to well over one-quarter, on a par with those to the NAFfA partners and well ahead of exports to the European Community. Since the mid-1980s, the trend rate of growth of US exports to the western Pacific has been three times the rate of growth of western Pacific exports to the United States. This rapid trade growth in the region and the prosperity it produces would be gravely threatened, in my view, if in coming decades North America and the western Pacific went separate ways in trade and strategic alignments. I am glad to be able to report that the Clinton administration is as convinced of the importance of the east Asia region as we ourselves have become. I had very productive discussions in Washington with President Clinton, Secretary of State Christopher, Defense Secretary Aspin, US Trade Representative Kantor, Treasury Secretary Bentsen, Director of the Central Intelligence Agency Woolsey, and senior congressional leaders including Senate Majority Leader Mitchell, Senate Minority Leader Dole and Speaker of the House of Representatives Foley. My meeting with President Clinton was exceptionally useful. I was impressed by the vigour, imagination and resolve with which he is going about the task of rebuilding American competitiveness and American society. We reaffirmed in our meeting the continuing vitality and relevance of Australia's bilateral relationship with the United States. spite the great changes in the world brought about by the end of the Cold War, fundamental Australian interests continue to be engaged in our relationship with the United States-in our defence alliance, in the mutually beneficial processes of policy consultation we enjoy on a wide range of issues, and in our strong commercial ties. Despite our bilateral access problemswhich I discussed with Ambassador Kantor and congressional leaders-the US market remains Australia's second biggest. Furthermore, the United States is the largest source one- of foreign investment in Australia and the most important destination for Australian investment abroad. . Mr Speaker, my meeting with the President produced three important results. First, we agreed to work closely together for a successful outcome of the informal APEC leaders meeting in Seattle in November. This historic meeting, involving leaders of the key Asia Pacific economies-the fastest growing area of the world-will help define an Asia-Pacific economic community and give political authority and weight to APEC. The President noted Australia's vital contribution to the development of APEC. I was impressed by the President's commitment to the Asia-Pacific economic community, and by the unanimity with which he, his cabinet and the congressional leadership in both houses and both parties expressed their conviction that the United States should assign a higher priority to its trading relations with the western Pacific. Secondly, we agreed that it was very important to world growth and jobs to achieve a successful and balanced outcome to the Uruguay Round by the 15 December deadline for fast-track approval by Congress, and that any move by the European Community to reopen the Blair House accord on agriculture would seriously jeopardise the whole round. The United States has pressed hard in favour of freer trade during seven long years of the GATT negotiations. It has been a policy stance of great value to Australia. But I was convinced by my discusDesions in Washington that 15 December is a real deadline for Congress, and that, if we cannot achieve an acceptable package by then, Congress as well as the administration will turn their attention away from global solutions to trade problems and towards more regional approaches. Thirdly, the President and Ambassador Kantor recognised Australia's concern about the damage that t.he export enhancement program, EEP, subsidies cause our grain exports, and said they would make every effort to minimise the effect on Australia's interests. They noted the administration's decision to stay out of the Indonesian market as a bona fide of their sincerity in this regard. They explained that the EEP was aimed at counteracting European subsidies, and that the only fully effective way to reduce the impact on Australia's grain exports was to conclude the Uruguay Round as soon as possible. Mr Speaker, in New York I addressed a meeting of the Asia Society and had a meeting with the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Mr Boutros Boutros Ghali. I told the Secretary-General that Australia welcomed the new possibilities for the work of the United Nations which have arisen with the disappearance of Cold War constraints. I said that, as a foundation member of the United Nations, Australia is fully committed to the ideals of the charter and wants to see those ideals prosper. I noted that Australia was committed to peacekeeping, with arol1nd 600 Australians serving in Cambodia, Somalia and in other operations around the globe. We were also a substantial financial contributor to the United Nations, paying in full and on time. I told the Secretary-General that Australia would continue to contribute resources and ideas to the organisation. The most recent example of this contribution is Senator Evans's document 'The United Nations: cooperating for peace', examining peacekeeping and conflict resolution, which is being launched in New York this week. I also' made it clear to the Secretary-General, however, that the United Nations Organisation itself had to make sure it was operating as efficiently and effectively as it couldespecially in its administration and in its peacekeeping operations-if it was to maintain the international support needed to fulfil its great potential. Mr Speaker, my visit to the United Kingdom, the first by an Australian Prime Minster since 1987, provided an opportunity to help reinforce and reshape this old and still very valuable relationship. I had a long and productive meeting in London with Prime Minister Major. World trade issues were again the main theme of my discussions. I told Prime Minister Major how much Australia appreciated the very constructive and positive role Britain has played within the EC, and more widely, in pushing the cause of freer world markets and the multinational trading system. We both underlined the importance of a successful and balanced outcome to the Uruguay Round for jobs and growth. We agreed that 15 December is a real deadline for the Uruguay Round. We also discussed the strong and growing economic ties between Britain and Australia. Britain is Australia's fourth largest trading partner, and our eighth largest export market. It is the second largest source of foreign investment in Australia. In tum, we are the fourth largest foreign investor in the UK, ranking above Japan. Prime Minister Major and I agreed that there was much to build on and to develop in this area. We noted that an important Australia-UK trade and investment conference, to be held in Melbourne in January next year, will help to maintain the impetus for growth in our commercial relationship. Mr Speaker, I also spoke to Prime Minister Major about Australia's constitutional arrangements. I said publicly in London that it is not because our affections for Britain are reduced or the friendship between us frailer, or our respect and admiration for the institutions Britain has bequeathed us in any way diminished, that Australia is considering the option of becoming a republic. And I also said that our friendship for Britain would be all the stronger for our becoming a republic, as any friendship is stronger for being more mature. Mr Major-Prime Minister of a Conservative British Government-and Mr Hurd, his Foreign Secretary who was on a parallel visit to Australia, both made publicly and privately clear that the matter of Australia's constitutional arrangements is one for the government, people and parliament of Australia and the Queen of Australia. They both assert, quite correctly, that the modern, mature relationship between Britain and Australia will remain quite unaffected by our moves to become a republic. Mr Speaker, I was received by-Her Majesty the Queen at Balmoral Castle on 18 September. In accordance with long standing convention, the discussion between us must remain confidential. But I am able to say I explained to Her Majesty that, notwithstanding the deep respect and warm affection felt towards her by the Australian people, there was a growing feeling in Australia that constitutional changes should be made to allow the appointment of an Australian head of state. I outlined to Her Majesty the various steps that would be involved in such a process, including the need for a referendum to approve constitutional amendments. I said the Australian government's view was that, if approved by the Australian people at a referendum, it would be appropriate for Australia to become a republic by the centenary of federation in 2001. I told Her Majesty that, in such a situation, Australia would remain a member of the Commonwealth of Nations, and that the Australian people would warmly welcome visits to Australia by Her Majesty as head of the Commonwealth and as the Queen of the United Kingdom. Her Majesty authorised me to say that she would, of course, act on the advice of her Australian ministers, as she always has, and on any decision made by the Australian people. The issues involved in the creation of a Federal Republic of Australia are complex. They require thoughtful and informed debate. But as a result of my discussions in Britain it is clear that, whatever the outcome of the debate in Australia, whatever the form of constitutional arrangements on which the Australian people finally decide, both Her Majesty and the British government regard these arrangements, properly, as entirely matters to be decided by the Australian people themselves. And it is also clear that the results of any constitutional changes are not seen as a threat-and will not threatenthe warmth of the relationship between Australia and Britain, or the personal respect and affection in which Her Majesty is held. It is my government's firm intention to ensure that, throughout the period that Australians are debating new constitutional arrangements, our existing links with the monarchy are maintained and exercised with dignity and respect. In that regard, I am pleased to announce that I discussed with Her Majesty an invitation I· have extended to the Prince of Wales to visit Australia early in 1994 following proposals by several state governments. The invitation has been accepted. His Royal Highness will arrive in Sydney on 25 January, and visit, in addition to New South Wales, Tasmania, Western Australia and Queensland. My visit to Ireland enabled me to mark the very important contribution which Ireland has made to the cultural, social and political development of this country. The people-topeople links between us are still strong and vigorous. In Dublin I had the honour of addressing the Dail, and I had extensive discussions with the Taoiseach, Mr Reynolds, and leaders of the other Irish political parties. My discussions focused again on the outcome for the Uruguay Round, on which Ireland has been orie of the European countries most resistant to change in the area of agriculture. I put the view forcefully to Irish political leaders, and to business people at a dinner hosted by the Irish-Australian Business Association, that Ireland, with its growing industrial exports, will be best served by ensuring that we get an acceptable outcome to the Uruguay Round. That in turn depended, I said, on the integrity of the Blair House accord on agriculture being fully maintained. I also made the point that, although our trade is growing, the warmth of people-topeople relations between Australia and Ireland is not matched by our commercial links. I said I hoped that companies in each country would increasingly use the other as a base to develop links into Asia and Europe respectively. The warmth displayed by the Irish people tow-rds me as head of the govetnment of Australia was quite profound. In aU parts of the country I visited, there was a spontaneous expression of warm welcome and good wishes towards Australia and the Australian people. It is quite a phenom-non that the cultural and emotional links between Australia and this small country in Europe exist as strongly as they do. It is something Australians should value and continue to nurture. On my way from Ireland to Monaco for the Sydney Olympic bid, I stopped for several hours in France and visited Villers-Bretonneux, the site of the memorial to the 46,000 Australians-18,OOO without a known gravewho died· on the Western Front during the First World War. Like all who have visited the military graveyards of France, I was reminded of the courage and devotion of those young Australians who fought and died in that terrible war and the huge loss this nation suffered on the French battlefields. I was also reminded that the tragedy of which they were victims arose, in large part, from the selfish and narrow nationalism which has so often scarred this century. We have the opportunity, as the century ends, to do things better, to create broader, more inclusive economic structures which will generate new growth and new jobs around the globe by maximising trading opportunities for all countries. If the international community fails in its efforts to resolve the Uruguay Round by mid-Decemb-r, there are other options available· but, as all those I spoke to on my visit agreed, they are not such good options The International Olympic Committee's decision to award the Olympic Games for the year 2000 to Sydney was a wonderful outcome for this country. The Olympics are bound to be a marvellous moment in the life of the city and the nation: a celebration of ternational youth and sport in a young country with extraordinary sporting traditions. All of Australia's attractions will be on show to billions of people around the world as we approach the centenary of the Commonwealth's creation. The Olympics can also be a defining moment in our history-in the 100th year of our nationhood, a brilliant opportunity to celebrate our achievements and define our place in the region and the world. The Olympics will generate economic growth and jobs well beyond Sydney itself. The IOC's decision was a tribute to all those who worked so hard to put together an outstanding bid. My wife and I were delighted to participate in the bid's presentation to the IOC, and were gratified that the government was able to indicate its material support for the bid. It is a tribute to the breadth of support for the games among the Australian communitydemonstrated so memorably by the tens of thousands of people who showed their enthusiasm in Sydney on Friday morning. In a wider sense, the IOC's decision is also a tribute to the society we have created hereits social equity, cultural diversity and tolerance, and its sophistication and efficiency. Sydney's approach was set apart from others by its technical excellence and by its commitment to the athletes themselves and to the ideals of the Olympic movement.· All the people involved in the bid deserve the warmest congratulations and thanks of this House. More than that, they deserve the continuing support of all Australians-government, business and the community-in the seven years of hard work that still lie ahead of us. I can say on behalf of the Commonwealth Government that they will have that support. I began by saying that my visit to the United· States and Europe took place at a time of great consequence for the world economy - a time when new patterns are being created, and when great decisions are being formed. Within the next 12 weeks alone we will have the first meeting of the leaders of the Asia Pacific Economic Community, we shall enjoy success or suffer failure in the Uruguay inRound, and we will have, by the year's end, a surer sense of whether recovery can take hold in Europe and Japan, and strengthen in the United States. It is a decisive time in world economic affairs and it comes as Australia is achieving greater international recognition. Sydney's Olympic win reflects this most dramatically, but it is also reflected in Mr Clinton's generous praise of Australia's role in forging APEC, and in the respect accorded to Australia's views in the Uruguay Round as the leader of the Cairns group of fair agriculture traders. There is a responsibility on all of us to recognise that we are in a bigger game-a game with bigger prizes but with new and tougher rules. The world is offering us great opportunities, but to take advantage of them we must continue to be flexible and competitive at home. We must continue to seek national cohesion and strength. We cannot seize the opportunities the world offers us if we cannot agree on the fundamental instrument of national economic policy, the budget. We cannot seize those opportunities if we cannot reach a satisfactory and enduring agreement on the implementation of the High Court's decision to recognise a form of Aboriginal title and we cannot seize those opportunities if our workplace relations are not free to evolve towards outcomes based on bargaining. To seize those opportunities we need to renew our commitment to change and our commitment to the reforms necessary to meet the imperatives of the new global order. It will help us in this regard if we recognise the success of the changes we have already made; how well we are doing in the world, how much more competitive we have made ourselves, how much the chances which now present themselves are only chances because of the changes we have made and how we have made them while also making Australia a tolerant, sophisti<;:ated and progressive society with few equals in the world-and how much better we can make it if we put aside sectional interest and parochialism and work together as a nation. I present the following paper: . Prime Minister: Overseas Visit-Ministerial Statement, 28 September 1993. Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed: That the House take note of the paper. Speaker: Dr HEWSON
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: Any visit by an Australian Prime Minister to the United States and to Europe is an important event. We on this side of the House welcome the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has met with President Clinton and senior members of the American administration. We also welcome the fact that the Prime Minister has met with the Prime Ministers of Britain and Ireland and with Her Majesty the Queen. No doubt, as the Prime Minister has indicated in his statement to the House today, a wide range of bilateral and international issues were addressed in these meetings. We on this side of the House share a bipartisan view on many of the issues that were raised, particularly the French intransigence on the Uruguay Round and the future possibilities for APEC. But as with whatever the Prime Minister does, he has claimed too much in relation to these international meetings. The time has come· to put some' perspective and some realism into what the Prime Minister and others are claiming about the so-called success of the Prime Minister's overseas trip. It is time to see some delusions of grandeur for what they are; it is time to take off the rosetinted glasses; it is time to cut through the journalistic hype; and it is time to examine exactly how Australia's national interests were advanced by.the Prime Minister's trip. The fact is this overseas visit by the Prime Minister was marked by some serious errors of judgment. First, there was some deliberate overselling of the significance of particular meetings and so-called guarantees given to the Prime Minister on particular issues. Second, there was a lack of clear strategic purpose about the objectives of many of the Prime Minister's discussions. Third, there was quite unjustified presumptuousness on the part of the Prime Minister in relation to the issue of an Australian republic. Finally, there was a preference to score cheap political points on the issue of European trade policies rather than to confront the issues directly with the European leaders involved. I will take this opportunity to address each these points in further detail in relation to the countries that the Prime Minister visited during his recent trip. Let me begin with his visit to the United States. The Prime Minister's visit to the United States provided him with an important opportunity to exchange views on key international issues-such as the future of the Uruguay Round, the prospects for APEC, the chall.enges facing UN peacekeeping and many more. No doubt some valuable exchanges of view took place and we on this side of the House certainly do not seek to diminish them. Furthennore, it is important that the Australian Prime Minister and the American President meet, and we appreciate the welcome that the American administration extended to our Prime Minister. But the visit was flawed by a number of factors. It began with a significant misjudgment. The Prime Minister's decision to decline to attend the historic signing of the peace agreement between the PLO and Israel was simply inexplicable. This dramatic development in the Middle East peace process is fundamentally important for international peace and security. It is also very important in tenns of Australia's interests. The Prime Minister's advisers were apparently deeply divided over whether or not he should attend. In the end, the Prime Minister decided not to do so for reasons that are quite inadequate. He claimed that he wanted to have talks with the US trade representative and the Treasury secretary; but these talks could surely have been rescheduled, just as most of the Prime Minister's other appointments in Washington were rescheduled. The Prime Minister said he did not attend the ceremony because Australia had not been directly involved in the peace process; but that did not stop hundreds of highly influential members of the American, Arab and Israeli communities from attending. Whatever the reason, the Prime Minister decided to tum his back on a truly historic occasion in which Australia had an important interest and which was attended by a very influential group of international leaders. It was a fundamental misjudgment· on the part of the Prime Minister. One particular feature of the Prime Minister's visit to Washington was its lack of any clear strategic purpose. Let me give the House three clear examples of how the Prime Minister's objectives waxed and waned as every day passed. First, the Prime Minister made it clear at the outset of his visit. that he inclination to take up with President Clinton particular policy issues, such as the export enhancement program and its effect on Australia. He said that he preferred discussions what he called 'big mainframe issues', such as GATT. He made it clear that taking up the concern of Australian fanners was a matter for others to do with their US counterparts and not for him to do with President Clinton.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: I did. That is wrong.

Speaker: Dr HEWSON
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: I am getting to exactly what the Prime Minister did; he backflipped. The response by the opposition and other critics in Australia to this statement of intent by the Prime Minister was swift in its condemnation. No-one could understand why an Australian Prime Minister could not do both; that is, to address the big issues of international trade and to put Australia's case directlyon the damage being inflicted on Australian fanners by American agricultural policy. The Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) rightly commented that the Prime Minister had given up before he had even started. Others simply could not understand how or why an Australian Prime Minister could choose not to raise the major irritant in Australia's bilateral relationship directly with the American J;>resident. What was the Prime Minister's response to all this criticism back here at home? It was, of course, his usual backflip. Under pressure, the agricultural subsidy issue was raised in discussions between the Prime Minister and President Clinton. We welcome that fact, but we regret that it occurred only after the Prime Minister's original intention to bypass the issue had been so vigorously and publicly criticised here in Australia. A second example of the lack of strategic purpose in the Prime Minister's visit can be found in his inept and ill-considered advice to the US administration to adopt a softer approach on the issue of human rights in Asia; The Prime Minister was apparently convinced that a hardening of the American position on human rights issues in China and Indonesia could jeopardise the future of the APEC process. The immediate response in Australia had no was criticism-from the opposition, the president of the ALP, various other members of the Labor Party, Amnesty International and other human rights groups and various editorion as in Australian newspapers. What was the Prime Minister's response? The usual backflip, together with an insistence that everyone else had again misunderstood him. The fact is that there was no misunderstanding. The Prime Minister had simply backflipped yet again in an attempt to cover his own tracks. Only 24 hours after he had had his spokesman briefing the media, to the effect that he had told senior administration figures that human rights should not be allowed to spoil trade negotiations, the Prime Minister was insisting that US foreign policy was in fact properly baIimced between concerns over human rights and the pursuit of commercial interests. The Prime Minister's intervention was inept and ill advised for many J:'easons. He showed absolutely no understanding of the subtle strategy of carrot and stick needed to encourage international. respect for basic standards of human rights. He showed no understanding of the well-established American political tra.dition in support of human rights and, in particular, of the commitment to human rights and to democracy that is fundamental to the Clinton administration's vision of a new Pacific community. The Prime Minister showed no understanding that political flexibility and economic growth are not mutually exclusive and that the defence of internationally accepted standardsof human rights can be pursued at the same time as a dynamic commercial relationship. The Prime Minister simply failed to understand that pandering after popularity anywhere on this basis will win no lasting respect from anyone. Finally, the Prime Minister has failed to recognise that the record of Australian governments over the past 10 years on the issue of human rights has been both confused and inconsistent and provides absolutely no basis for lecturing countries such .as the United States. President Clinton put the American position very clearly. He made it quite clear that he could see nothing wrong with the way the United States had handled its human rights concerns. He said that the strong US position on human rights had not undermined its commercial and political relationships with countries that were making an honest effort to deal' with the United States. He conCluded: The United States does have a very strong position on human rights and I think we should. By now the Prime Minister was looking faintly ridiculous on the issue of human rights, and even he must have been regretting his decision to give the United States some coaching 9n this whole matter. The interventionof the Prime Minister into this complex area of foreign policy was not clearly thought through. It exposed its shallow and selfserving quality and it forced the Prime Minister to back off and to go quiet on what had been an unfortunate and damaging series ' of comments. A third example of the Prime Minister's lack of strategic purpose on his overseas trip lay in the views he expressed on the North American free trade agreement-NAFTA. Just over a year ago, when it suited his domestic political purposes to do so, the Prime Minister was happy to go around the country deriding and condemning NAFTA. Honourable members will recall that when the Prime Minister went to Japan, for example, he made a deliberate point of setting up a phoney choice between Australian trade with the United States and Australian trade with Japan. He set up another phoney choice between NAFTA and APEC. None of these phoney choices derived from realities about international trade; it was just the Prime Minister playing out his own domestic political game on the international stage. It should come as no surprise to anyone, therefore, that it now suits the Prime Minister to take an entirely different approach to the issue of NAFTA. Overcome by his environment in Washington where three former Presidents, as well as President Clinton, were pushing for congressional approval of NAFTA, the Prime Minister's new position is that NAFTA is the key to saving the US from protectionism. He now says NAFTA and APEC are consistent and mutually supportive. This flip-flop is represented by the Prime Minister as some kind of dramatic new trade strategy for Australia in a world where the Uruguay Round is under threat. The fact is that there is absolutely nothing new in anything that the Prime Minister has suddenly discovered about international trade. We on this side of the House have been telling the government for years that it has been putting excessive faith in multilateral solutions to international trade problems that confront Australia. We have been telling it that bilateral and regional issues were ignored for too long, and we have been telling it that NAFfA offered opportunities for Australia and not the massive dangers with which the Prime Minister tried to scare Australians in the course of last year. I am very pleased that the Prime Minister has now changed his view of NAFfA and that his political stunt in Japan last year has now been exposed for exactly what it was. I am also pleased that his views about NAFfA are now much more in accord with what we have been saying about it in the last year. The real danger in what the Prime Minister was saying in Washington about international trade is· that he is now trying to set up a new kind of saviour. He is trying to make regional trade initiatives like APEC into some kind of panacea for all of Australia's economic problems. The fact is that APEC alone will not solve our economic problems. Our economic problems demand that we take the necessary decisions to put our own economic house in order, and only then will we be in a position to take advantage of the trade opportunities that might be presented by APEC. Furthermore, the Prime Minister speaks of APEC as though there is general agreement in the region about what it should be and how it should be advanced. The fact is that there is no such consensus in either the United States or the wider Asia-Pacific region. I have recently had discussions about the future of APEC with the new Japanese government and with Thai political leaders. The common theme of their comments was that Asian views of the role of APEC are very divergent: some see it as a vehicle for regional trade liberalisation; some see it as a means for keeping America involved in the region; some see it as a threat to ASEAN's interests; and others see it as little more than a forum in which to exchange views and are opposed to quantitative trade liberalisation objectives. there is a need to view anything that the Prime Minister has to say about APEC through a prism of realism. APEC, of course, is important. It is important that it becomes a means of genuine regional trade liberalisation, but it is not a panacea for Australia's economic problems and it is quite uncertain as to how it will proceed, given the significant differences of view that exist in the region at present. The major selling point which the Prime Minister has used in relation to his American visit has been his so-called special personal relationship that he claims to have established with President Clinton. Let me be very clear that we on our side of this House believe that it is very important for an American President and an Australian Prime Minister to have a good working and personal relationship. This has existed for many years. Most Australian Prime Ministers from the time of John Curtin on have enjoyed a special rapport with their American counterparts, and if an outcome of the Prime Minister's recent visit is that this kind of rapport is to continue then of course we welcome it. But, as with APEC, a dose of realism is needed when we look at what the Prime Minister has to say about the personal relationship he now claims with the President. First, there is only so much that any personal relationship between Australian and American leaders can achieve. The Congress has its own capacity for action in the United States, particularly in relation to issues like agricultural subsidies. Bob Hawke had a special personal relationship with George Bush, but that did not stop the export enhancement program from inflicting significant damage on Australian farmers. Second, it is important not to misrepresent what are the normal courtesies and politeness of American political life, and not to read special meaning into them for partisan political purposes. Quite frankly, it becomes somewhat absurd when the Prime Minister's office starts reading special significance into the strength of handshakes or looks in the eye. Third, despite the obvious goodwill of President Clinton, it is not the first time that an Australian Prime Minister has received So such an assurance from an American President to do all that he could to ensure that Australian trading interests were not harmed by American policies. This is not the dramatic kind of breakthrough the Prime Minister is claiming, nor is it significantly different similar assurances given to previous Prime Ministers by previous American Presidents. But the Prime Minister has decided to elevate it into something that it is not on the back of what he claims to be a special personal relationship. , The comments of President Clinton, into which the Prime Minister is reading so much, were to the effect that the United States will do all that it can to avoid using EEP, the export enhancement program, in ways that will damage Australia's trade interests. But it is quite unclear how EEP in any form will not harm Australian farmers. Even if American assurances not to extend EEP further into Australia's traditional markets are in fact honoured to the letter, the depressing effect EEP on commodity prices will still impact directly oli Australian farmers. We on this side of the House appreciate President Clinton's expression of goodwill, but we are dubious about the Prime Minister's overselling of it and we will hold the Prime Minister to account for the gloss that he has put on it. Finally, in relation to the Prime Minister's American visit, may I just note the unfortunate precedent that he has set in relation to comments on domestic political issues in Australia. Bob Hawke took a principled stand on this issue: he simply refused to comment. The current Prime Minister takes a different approach-what I would describe as a coward's approach. He comments on domestic political issues when he thinks he can score a point, but he hides behind convention in refusing to comment when he is in trouble. In a question and answer session following his Asia Society speech in New York, the Prime Minister chose to deliberately misrepresent the opposition's policy and strategy in response to his government's disastrous budget. This was a totally inappropriate action from an Australian Prime Minister while overseas. By the way, what he said was totally wrong. I was travelling in Japan and Thailand at the time that the Prime Minister was in America. I had the opportunity to criticise the government for its failed budget and its general incompetence over recent months but from I refused to do so because of established conventions. The Prime Minister should adopt the same approach or else he will be inviting us to play by his new rules, which will be to the detriment of Australia's international interests. From the United States, the Prime Minister went to Britain where he met the Prime Minister and the Queen. When in Britain, the Prime Minister made two totally indefensible assertions on the republican issue. Firstly, he asserted that the Australian people wanted a republic. In a speech at Australia House the Prime Minister said: It is not because the machinery is broken that we wish to change it. It is because a great many Australians-in all likelihood, a majority of Ausof tralians-believe the machinery is no longer most appropriate. The fact is that there is simply no evidence for that assertion· because there is no community consensus on any alternative to current constitutional arrangements. Secondly, the Prime Minister reported that he had told the Queen that he would make Australia a republic by the year 2001 even though he has not told anyone in Australia what kind of republic and what kind of constitutional changes he wants to make. This is presumptuousness of an arrogant and dangerous kind. We have made it clear for many months that, if the Prime Minister wants to change the Australian constitution that has worked extraordinarily well, he must argue a case for change and he has so far totally failed to do so. He presumes that the only debate is over the kind of republican change that is needed, whereas the real debate that he should be focusing on is whether Australians want any republican change at all-and that is far from clear. The Prime Minister was totally wrong to present the republican issue to the Queen in the way he did because his whole presentation was built on a phoney assumption about what the Australian people will ultimately. decide. He was also totally wrong to claim, as he did in his statement here in the House today, that as a result of his discussions in Britain it had become clear that Her Majesty and the British government regarded Australia's constitutional arrangements as matters to be decided by the Australian people. That fact has nothing to do with the Prime Minister's visit. It is a constitutional reality that Her Majesty and the British government properly pointed to. That is all it is. In Ireland, the Prime Minister had an opportunity to make European agricultural subsidies, which are strongly supported by the Irish government, the focus of his visit. But instead, he preferred sentimentality, personal indulgence and a good deal of rewriting of Australian history as the focus of his Irish visit. The Prime Minister told the Irish parliament about the virtues of republicanism for Australia. He said: . . . a republic might acknowledge values of a people who have been willing to imagine something better, willing to confront the need to change, to make their way on a new frontier ... But what the Prime Minister has to tell Austra,lians is how a republic will give them something better. He has to tell them how it will be. a brave new frontier. The Prime Minister has done none of these things because he knows that such rhetoric is absolute tripe. It has got no basis of support in the Australian community and to try to convince the Irish parliament or anyone else that it does is totally wrong. The Prime Minister went even further on Irish television by saying that he was a republican because he was a Catholic. This stirring of the old sectarian fires that went out long ago in Australia was totally uncalled for and totally ridiculous, but then again this Prime Minister is the most divisive Prime Minister we have ever had in our history, and sees political advantage in community division. The Prime Minister's visit to VillersBrettoneux was obviously a very emotional experience, as it is to every Australian who visits the region. Two days before, I had visited the area of the Western Front battlefields, met with the local mayors and laid a wreath at the Villers-Brettoneux Memorial.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: You are always following me around; why don - t you do your own itinerary?

Speaker: Dr HEWSON
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: I was two days ahead of the Prime Minister. It ranks with my visit to Gallipoli for the 75th anniversary as one of the most moving experiences of my life. Those rows of crosses marking the graves of Australians are a reminder of extraordinary Australian sacrifice and extraordinary Australian valour. I have to say, however, that I was very disappointed that the Prime Minister chose such an occasion to link the sacrifices of Australians 75 years ago with current French agricultural policies. In my view, a visit to the Western Front battlefields is a time for reflection, for gratitude and for remembrance. Making a visit to Villers-Brettoneux or other memorials in the region the occasion for trying to score a political point demeaned the and enshrine the occasion . All of us are opposed to French agricultural policies but, if the Prime Minister felt so strongly about the issue, he should have gone to Paris and confronted President Mitterrand on the issue directly. Attacking a local French politician at Villers-Brettoneux was a very poor substitute. As yesterday's editorial in the West Australian put it, the Prime Minister 'undervalues the lives of young Australians if he believes they can be used as a bargaining chip'. The Prime Minister ought to listen to that. He undervalues the lives of young Australians if he thinks that they can be used as a bargaining chip. The final leg of the Prime Minister's overseas visit was to join the Australian Olympic delegation, as I did, to support the Sydney bid for the 2000 Olympics. The outcome of the bid is· now well known and a matter of pride to all Australians. I wish to take this opportunity to congratulate all those in New South Wales, led by Premier John Fahey, and all those around Australia who worked so hard to make the Sydney bid a success. The buildup and result in Monaco were a memorable experience and a great result for Sydney, for our nation and for all Australians. The success in Monaco was due to the highly successful nature of the bid and to the obvious community support-including, importantly, bipartisan political supportwhich it enjoyed throughout Australia. It provides a great opportunity for Australians to start believing in themselves again. It shows how we really can take on the best in the world and win. But I have to say that the Prime Minister was unfortunately quick to inject a sour note of political opportunism. Within hours of the result, he was talking about its implications for Australian 'independence', that wonderful word, which is his phoney code for republicanism. On the Prime Minister's return to Australia, as soon as he got off the plane, he dashed off to a television interview to tell Australians how he would use the Olympic decision to accelerate his republican ambitions. The Prime Minister is playing a very dangerous game by linking politics with sport. Australians love their sport, but they do not like politics intruding into sport. The Prime Minister's ham-fisted attempt to politicise Sydney's Olympic success is totally inappropriate and totally unacceptable. It is nothing more than divisive. We saw part of his hidden agenda revealed in this parliament when the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) stood up and said that the Olympics ought to be used to change the flag by 1996. Is that the Prime Minister's policy? Is it his policy to change the flag by 1996 and to use the Olympics for that purpose? We on this side of the House know that Sydney, and Australia, will stage a magnificent Olympics, and we look forward to a bipartisan political approach in support of that goal. But, above all, we hope that Australians can enjoy these Olympic games free from the Prime Minister's hang-ups and obsessions. The sooner he forgets trying to use the Olympics to push his own republican barrow, the better it will be for all Australians. The Prime Minister said that Australia would not make the most of its opportunities in the world and of the opportunity to host the Olympic games if Australians did not sign on to his republican agenda, pass his budget, agree to his Mabo solution or toe his line on industrial relations. This is a totally ridiculous argument. Australia will not realise its great potential in the world until he shows some leadership and some government in Australia; until his government is prepared to act in the national interest-to put our economic house in order, to reduce our record unemployment and record foreign debt, to make our export industries internationally competitive, to restore incentive, dynamism and genuine fairness in our society, and to focus on the creation of Australian wealth rather than the distribution of what is now a shrinking wealth. Only when we have a government that is generally committed to these objectives will Australia assume its rightful place in the region and in the world. Debate (on motion by Mr Howe) adjourned. NA

Title: HOUSE MONITORING SERVICE

NA Broadcasting of Parli.amentary Proceedings, Committee Motion (by Mr Beazley) agreed to: (1) That the following matter be referred· to the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings for inquiry and report: the arrangements which may apply in res-t of the televising and radio broadcasting of the proceedings of the Houses of Parliament and their committees, including a review of the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act 1946 (the act), with particular reference to: (a) the general principles upon which radio broadcast, delayed broadcast and rebroadcast of proceedings of both Houses and their committees occur and conditions for.broadcasting of audio-only excerpts of proceedings; (b) in relation to the television signal of proceedings: (i) the feasibility of encompassing within the act arrangements applying to the televising of proceedings of each House and its committees, and joint committees; (ii) the formulation of general principles upon which televising of proceedings of both Houses and their committees occurs, the allocation arrangements between the houses and conditions for usage of videotape excerpts of proceedings; and (iii) review of arrangements for making available to bodies external to Parliament House, Canberra, the signal of proceedings distributed by means of the house monitoring service; and (c) the establishment of a permanent, Australia wide parliamentary broadcast network under parliamentary control. Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: ADJOURNMENT OF THE HOUSE
text: I move: That standing order 48A, Adjournment of the House, and standing order 103, 11 o'clock rule, be suspended for all sittings up to and including Thursday, 28 October 1993. Reference Honourable members will see from the Notice Paper that a very substantial number of bills are to be introduced into this House over the next couple of days. By the end of this week, some 60 bills will have to be debated before we reach the opposition's imposed deadline of 28 October. As we are trying to put through about 60 bills in a few sitting weeks, we will have to work longer hours and also operate under the guillotine. This proposition is a continuation of the things which have had to be done in this place since the opposition in the Senate-for reasons that we on this side of the House find unfathomabledetermined that, unless we introduced legislatidn by the end of this week and unless we passed it out of this place by the end of next month, the Senate would not consider itself in a position, unless given a very good reason, to consider further legislation during this year. This proposition on the opposition's part imposes burdens on two groups of people. It imposes a very substantial burden on members of the opposition in this place, because it obliges the government to massively speed up its legislation and to ensure that the House concentrates on no other matters. The second group of people that it massively imposes a burden on is the parliamentary draftsmen. In circumstances of limited time, mistakes will always be made in drafting--ven with the best will in the world. Drafting is a complex exercise and, even with stacks of time, mistakes will be made. In circumstances where time is short, mistakes will be made in greater profusion. This does not impose any burden at all on the government of the day. It means, as far as we are concerned, that this House operates like clockwork. We have a perfect excuse to consider allowing no censure motions or matters of public importance. We are left in a situation where this House becomes a quiet, broad green meadow on which we may safely graze. It is an act of utter political stupidity for an opposition to put this set of propositions in place. Having put it in place, there are consequences which the government has to impose. Some of those consequences will be seen as we guillotine some legislation, and more will be guillotined subsequently. Some of it can be seen now because, in order to give any decent consideration to this legislation, the parliament will have to suspend the 11 o'clock rule and we will have to sit later at night.

Title: URGENT LEGISLATION
text: I move: TIult, in relation to the proceedings on the following Bills, so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the' House making one declaration of urgency and moving one motion for the allotment of time in respect.of all the Bills: Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.1) 1993; Taxation (Deficit Redu'?tion) Bill (No.2) 1993; Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.3) 1993; Sales Tax (Customs) (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993; .
