Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Northern Territory-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training) (5.43 p.m.)-I move: PAIRS That the bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 in accordance with the 1993-94 budget decisions and other decisions made by the government in respect of higher education. This bill provides over $4.6 billion for higher education in 1996, including some $500 million to be provided by the government through the BEeS trust account.. As well, the bill provides for funds that are additional to those already legislated for. These additional funds total over $50 million in 1993, over $270 million in 1994 and over $320 million in 1995. Measures put forward in the bill will also generate additional revenues of $126 million in 1994, $186 million in 1995 and $130 million in 1996. The government has framed the measures covered in this bill to meet the need for enhanced efficiencies in higher education funding. These measures will also advance national goals relating to access, equity, diversity and quality in the system. The bill's provisions include amendments to the contributions made by certain categories of students under the higher education contribution scheme-HECS. The changes require students who have already had access to undergraduate, professional and postgraduate opportunities to contribute, in general, twice the standard rate of HECS from January 1994 should they enrol in a second undergraduate course. The level of government subsidy will also be reduced for students at both the undergraduate and postgraduate levels who have already undertaken the required number of equivalent full-time student units to complete a course of study, plus a further allowance of half a standard student load. Except in special circumstances, these students will be liable for 1.5 times standard rate of HECS for additional study undertaken for that course. The reasons for these changes are very simple. Every student who takes or is allowed by his or her university to take longer than necessary to complete or do a second undergraduate degree is excluding a school leaver or another person from attending university at all. Other measures put forward in this bill modify repayment arrangements for HECS. From July 1994, repayment rates will be lifted from the present two, three and four per cent levels to three, four and five per cent respectively. Concurrently with this change, income thresholds for repayment of the HECS debt will be re-aligned with actual average weekly earnings. In addition, from July 1994 HECS repayments will be made on a PAYE and provisional tax basis. The HECS amendments in this bill are both equitable and realistic. The measures relating to the amount of contributions stress that as many Australians as possible should have access to higher education and that those who do have the chance to participate should contribute to the cost of that experience in the fairest way possible. These amendments acknowledge that in a climate of budgetary restraint the opportunities of newcomers to the system, including recent schoolleavers, have to be protected and that our students need to think very carefully about their study options. The amendments complement other initiatives which the government is undertaking, in the context of its educational profile negotiations with institutions, to restore opportunities for those new to higher education, especially recent school leavers. All the HECS measures introduced in this bill will reduce Commonwealth government outlays to higher education and hence the public sector financial burden. HECS is not a tax. It is a deferred repayment loans system. As such, it is in the first instance a government outlay and any reduction in student contributions requires greater government expenditure. Income received through HECS is directly linked to the Commonwealth's ability to provide additional student places. In the the same way as HECS has already provided opportunities for more Australians to participate in higher education, the HECS measures in this bill are essential for the government to meet its ongoing commitment to. increased access. The provisions relating to income thresholds and the rates at which the HECS debt is repaid shorten the repayment period-from 15 to nine years for the typical graduatewithout increasing the actual cost to students. These measures also recognise that Commonwealth funding of the massive growth in higher education since 1989 has substantially exceeded HECS revenue. For example, income from HECS last year, including up-front payments, voluntary repayments and payments against HECS debt assessments by the Australian Taxation Office amounted to about $195 million. This was less than 5 per cent of the total Commonwealth 1992 outlay on higher education of $4.3 billion, which was $274 million above the level of funding provided in 1991. Outstanding HECS debts currently total in excess of $2 billion. Under another measure introduced in this bill, students undertaking at least 75 per cent of a full-time study load through the. new open learning initiative, OLI, will have access to a deferred payment facility similar to HECS. The OLI is already extending opportunities for a significant number of Australians who would otherwise find it difficult to participate in higher education by virtue of work commitments or other circumstances. Provision already exists for the government to fund the development of a decentralised network to support open learning students. A deferred payment facility will further help these Australians by making it easier for them to make the required contribution to the costs involved in their education. Additional growth in higher education for 1994 and 1995 has already been announced. This bill further expands opportunities for access in 1995 and 1996 with its provisions concerning any spare capacity which institutions may have. The bill's amendments in respect of research and postgraduate education funding reflect the government's policy of encouraging the higher education sector to maintain and strengthen its quality of provision and higher international standing. The government will continue the research infrastructure program beyond 1994 at an enhanced level, providing $56.4 million in 1995 and $60 million from 1996 with total infrastructure program funding amounting to $176.4 million over the 1995-97 triennium. From January 1994, the government will integrate the Australian postgraduate research awards, the Australian postgraduate course awards andHECS exemption scholarships into a single Australian postgraduate awards scheme. There will be 20,700 of these new awards available in 1994, rising to 25,500 in 1997, an increase that will help expand participation in postgraduate education and thereby assist Australia to enhance its competitive edge in higher education and research. These measures will complement the further deregulation of postgraduate provision, allowing universities to build a postgraduate fee paying market. Universities will be free to innovate, for example, by using Commonwealth postgraduate load to subsidise feepaying students. The government's commitment to increasing the efficiency, flexibility and productivity of the higher education labour market is reflected in its support for the introduction of workplace bargaining. A national framework agreement for agency bargaining is imminent which the government will support. This bill provides for on-going supplementation to be made available to universities for funding economic adjustments consistent with the Australian Public Service arrangements which provide 1.4 per cent followed by 1.5 per cent twelve months later. The arrangements cover both academic and general staff. In addition, the government will offer to each institution an advance of funds for a sector-wide productivity related salary increase of up to two per cent for both academic and general staff. This would be conditional on there being agreement as regards a broad range of productivity related measures. There will be no on-going supplementation provided by the government for productivity related salary increases. The bill seeks to consolidate amounts at present specified separately in the legislation for quality, research, equity, the national priority (reserve) fund and advanced engineering centres. The distribution of funds across these programs is determined three years in advance but allocations to universities for most of these programs are made annually. This unnecessarily inhibits the capacity of government and higher education institutions to respond to needs that emerge over the course of a triennium. While this bill proposes the consolidation of funding, the specific purposes for which grants can be made will remain unaltered and programs will not be administratively affected. While the total level of available funding will continue to be legislated three years in advance, allocations will be decided annually and announced in the yeady higher education funding report. The value of this measure lies in the increased fle:cibility it will accord to recurrent funding arrangements. This will in turn assist universities and the Commonwealth to achieve their objectives with greater efficiency. In summary, the measures put forward in this bill are part of the government's overall strategy for· enhancing the efficiency and effectiveness of the higher education sector. These measures seek to expand opportunities for Australians while recognising that' there are limits to the contribution available from the taxpayer. They aim, in addition, to stimulate Australia 1s diverse higher. education sector to maximise its capacity for providing a high quality product that meets the needs of its students and the nation as a whole. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and commend the bill to the House. Debate (on motion ,by Mr Ronaldson) adjounied. Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: DOMESTIC MEAT PREMISES
text: Hotham-Minister for Primary Industries and Energy) (5.52 p.m.)I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this bill is to provide for a per premises charge to be levied on domestic meat establishments in those states and territories where the Commonwealth's meat inspection agency, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, is responsible for inspecting domestic meat. Since the bill is the first part of a package of legislation to be introduced, I want to spend some time on the context, objectives and impacts of the whole package before returning to the details of this particular bill. The House will also see that the Senate's imposed deadlines for the passage of legislation through this House impacts on the package of measures and the timing of their introduction. In the 1993 budget, the government announced a major program of reform of AQIS to reduce its cost to Australian industry while retaining the integrity of Australia's inspection functions. I want to make it clear that AQIS fulfils an. essential role in protecting Australia against the importation of exotic pests and diseases and inspecting food for safety and overseas country requirements. This role must continue, but I believe it can be done more efficiently at lower cost to Australia:n industry. The program of reform of AQIS, which is designed to give the organisation a much stronger business orientation, has three major elements. First,' AQIS will be reflecting the government's intention to actively encourage Australian industry to take more responsibility for quality assurance from production, through processing and distribution, to consumption. Industry will benefit from quality assurance by adopting modem technology and processing systems giving much better' control of their products. Second, to improve the efficiency of service a delivery to' industry and to cap and reduce inspection costs, AQIS will be restructured over the next three to four years with a projected decline of 650 Commonwealth and 100 state AQIS personnel via retrenchments on a voluntary basis wherever possible. To place this in perspective, AQIS currently employs around 2,000 Commonwealth and 600 state permanent staff. Third, a package of new charging legislation will be introduced to provide for a uniform, three-tiered charging regime for AQIS services. To implement this new charging regime across all AQIS services to export, import and domeStic industries, a considerable package of new legislation is expected to be introduced to the House of Representatives late in the budget session with passage through the Senate in the autumn session. With the exception of the meat industry, implementation of the new. three-tiered charge regime across the industries' AQIS services will be on or after 1 July 1994. Introduction of the the--tiered charging regime is essential if charge:, are to be acceptable and equitable across all users whether their inspection services are based on quality assurance methods or traditional end point inspection. The three tiers of the new charge structure comprise: first tier, a fixed annual charge per premises at which activity is conducted; second tier, a throughput or volume charge on relevant products; third tier, a charge per inspector per unit of time, or a charge per inspection. The third tier inspection· charge aims to recover the variable costs of AQIS field inspection activities. The first· and second tier charges between them aim. to recover the balance of AQIS chargeable costs which tend by their nature to be fixed in the short to medium term. The three-tiered charging regime allows for· the separation and identification of AQIS field and other costs. It contrasts sharply with present AQIS charges, the bulk of which are set on an average, per inspector per unit of time basis. The objectives of the three-tiered approach to the pricing of AQIS services are efficiency, equity, consistency, transparency and simplicity. To meet the efficie-cy objective, economic theory suggests that the marginal cost of addi-ional inspection resources equates with the price industry pays to deploy them as it will with third tier charges. For equity, the three-tiered cost recovery regime provides a fairer allocation of the costs to be recovered from firms participating in the industry particularly when quality assurance methods become more widespread. AQIS costs will be measured and applied consistently across industries with the application of the three-tiered regime which is based on common princil?les. As a public monopoly providing regulatory services, AQIS needs to be able to justify its pricing policies to its clients. It also needs make its costs and recoveries visible to them. Taken together these imply transparency and simplicity to which the three-tiered charging regime contributes. However, due to the shortness of time made available by the Senate for the drafting and introduction of budget bills and to ensure that the government's reform plans for the domestic and export meat industries and their associated charging structures are introduced progressively from 1 January 1994 as planned, I am currently introducing two bills for passage of both the House and the Senate in the budget sittings relating solely to the domestic and export meat industry charging arrangements. As I stated initially, the purpose of the bill before us is to provide for a first tier, per premises charge to be levied on domestic meat establishments. The second bill, whose introduction will follow immediately, makes consequential changes to the name and coverage of the collection act. Other changes to domestic and export meat charges, including an export meat premises charge to be made on 1 January 1994, can be made by amending the relevant subordinate legislation of other acts. The second tier,· throughput charge for export and domestic meat, is not proposed for introduction until 1 July 1994, so its imposition has been included in the full package of AQIS charging legislation due to be introduced late in these budget sittings. I want to tum now to the financial impact of the three-tiered charge regime and the other changes proposed on the meat industry. The estimated revenues are all expressed in today's dollars and using accrual accounting concepts. In 1994-95, the first full year of the three-tiered charging system, AQIS revenue from the domestic and export meat industry is expected to be around $78.2 million, which will include a maximum of $13.2 million in premises charges. This compares with meat inspection revenue of $80.6 million in both 1992-93 and 1993-94, Revenue is expected to fall in subsequent years, reaching $70.5 million in 1996-97. When the premises charges are introduced to on 1 January 1994, the annual cost of meat inspection staff is expected to fall from a base rate of $69,169 to $65,164. The base rate is expected to fall further to $59,164 on 1 July 1994. This will honour the government's dual pledges not to increase the costs of inspection staff and to reduce the total costs of inspection services by AQIS to the meat industry by $10 million over the next four years. Revenue from first tier premises charges on domestic meat establishments is estimated by AQIS to total $1.1 million in 1993-94 and $2.2 million in 1994'-95, the first full year of its operation. As previously explained, the revenue collected from the premises charge will be offset by a reduction in the revenue from the third tier inspection charge. This bill and the foreshadowed amendment bill are part of major and worthwhile reforms to AQIS and the charging regime for its services .. The reform of AQIS charging regimes will be completed when I introduce a full package of legislation late in the budget sittings. I commend the bill to honourable members and I present the explanatory memorandum. Debate (on motion by Mr Ronaldson) adjourned. Title: EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGES
text: Rotham-Minister for Primary Industries and Energy) (5.02 p.m.)I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this bill is to amend the following Acts: the Export Inspection Charges Collection Act 1985, the Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Act 1985, the Export Inspection (Establishment Regulation Charges) Act 1985 and the Export (Service Charge) Act 1985. As I stated earlier today when I delivered the se,cond reading speech on the Domestic; Meat Premises Charge Bill 1993, this amendment bill and the earlier bill allow for the implementation of a three-tiered charging regime for the meat inspection services of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection 'Service. I refer honourable members to my earlier second reading speech on the context of the government's reforms of AQIS, including the three-tiered charging arrangements-of which this bill forms a part. It is the government's intention to seek the leave of the Rouse to have a concurrent debate on the two bills. I will now provide a summary for honourable members of the effect of the amendments. The short title of the Export Inspection Charges Collection Act 1985 will be amended to read Export Inspection and Meat Charges Collection Act 1985. It also amends this collection act to authorise the collection of the domestic meat premises charge which is to be imposed by the Domestic Meat Premises Charge Bill 1993. The bill ;llso amends the Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Act 1985, the Export Inspection (Export Registration Charge) Act 1985 and the - Export Inspection (Service Charge) Act 1985 to refer to the new title of the collection act. The bill has no direct financial implications. I commend the bill to, honourable members and I present the explanatory - emorandum. Debate (on rnotion by Mr Ronaldson) adjourned. NA (TRANSFER OF ASSETS AND LIABILITIES) BILL 1993 First Reading  first time. " Second Reading  tary to the Minister for Defence) (5.05 p.m.) - I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The Financial Corporations (Transfer of Assets and Liabilities) Bill 1993 derives from the banking policy statement of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) on 18 June 1993, and relates to the government's decision to liberalise foreign bank entry, announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the One Nation statement. The Banking Act 1959 has already been amended by the Banking Legislation Amendment Act 1992, which received the royal assent on 21 December 1992, to give effect to the government's decision in One Nation to liberalise foreign bank entry. Those amendments enable foreign banks, whether they have been operating in Australia or not, to apply for a banking authority under section 9 of the Banking Act 1959; and permit foreign banks, which are authorised under the Banking Act, to operate as banks in the form of a branch. ' The purpose of the current bill is to facilitate the transfer of certain assets and liabilities from foreign bank subsidiaries 'in Australia to new branches. These subsidiaries will have been in existence prior to 18 June 1993 and may be either authorised banks under section 9 of the Banking Act 1959, or money market corporations registered under the Financial Corporations Act 1974-or any subsidiaries of those bodies which ar- registered under the Financial Corporations Act' 1974. In a limited number of cases the transfer may be between a pre-existing subsidiary and a new authorised bank subsidiary. To be eligible to transfer assets and liabilities under the proposed legislation, foreign banks will have, from the commencement of the legislation, three years within which to apply for a banking authority, and up to six years to effect the transfer. The proposed legislation will minimise administrative procedures, and waive the payment of both Commonwealth and state transfer fees and charges. Without these changes foreign banks would be inhibited from responding to the government's policy decision to encourage increased effective competition and efficiency in the Australian financial sector. The Financial Corporations (Transfer of Assets and Liabilities) Bill 1993 will facilitate the establishment of branch operations in Australia by ensuring that foreign banks currently operating an authorised bank subsidiary or money mC;lrket corporation are not disadvantaged compared with new foreign bank entrants when establishing branch bankillg operations in Australia. The bill also makes a number of changes to the income tax law to ensure that the tax consequences that would normally' arise· on the transfer of business from foreign bank subsidiaries to branches are deferred, and that double taxation and double deductions do not arise. To do this, the bill places the branch in the same position as the subsidiary would have been in had its assets and liabilities not been transferred. This treatment will extend to all assets and liabilities transferred under this legislation, including debts owing to the subsidiary that are transferred to the branch and are subsequently written off as bad. Also, any interest paid on borrowings transferred to the branch, which would have been exempt from interest withholding tax under section 128F of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 if paid by .the subsid1ary, will be exempt under the same provision. \ !' ' To further assist the smooth transition from subsidiary to branch banking, the subsidiaries of foreign banks will be able tq transfer existing tax losses to branches of the banks. In this way; the ability to claim deductions for past tax losses will not be disturbed by the transition to branch banking. The government believes that these changes will bring competitive gains and efficiencies to the banking sector; greater flexibility in the provision of finance; and cost advantages to Australian clients. The measures contained in the bill should also further improve the international competitiveness of the Australian financial system. I present the explanatory memorandum, which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the bill. I commend the bill to the House. Debate (on motion' by Mr Ronaldson) adjourned. . CUSTOMS AND EXCISE NA 1993 First Reading·  first time. Second Reading  tary to the Minister for Defence) (6.10p.m.) - I move: That the bill be now read a second time. This bill is part of a package of bills introducing the following measures. Firstly, there will be amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act' 1901 to amend the diesel' fuel rebate scheme to restrain the escalating costs of that scheme by: establishing a time limit of three years after the purchase of fuel, for claims for rebate; introducing an annual adjustment of the rebate rates because of indexation of the duty rates applying to diesel fuel. This is considered to be an improvement to the previous system which adjusted the rates of rebate twice yearly-in February and August-but then averaged out these increases through the use of a six-monthly moving average. It is considered that the proposed improvement will, in addition to restraining costs under scheme, simplify its administration; and finally, imposing an administration charge of one per cent of the value of the rebate payable to claimants. Secondly, there will be amendments to the Excise Act 1901, together with amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921, to address revenue loss due to the practice of brewing beer with the aid of commercial facilities in unlicensed premises, known as microbreweries and, in particular, to ensure that beer produced at microbreweries is subject both to customs control and to duties of excise. While the excise revenue loss is relatively minor at present, overseas experience indicates the potential for substantial revenue erosion. Thirdly, there will be amendments to the Excise Act 1901, together with amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921, to address substantial revenue loss through the substitution of excise free or low duty products for petroleum fuels. Resolution of this issue involves ensuring· certain blended petroleum products and crude oil or condensate delivered for use otherwise than as refinery feedstock are excisable products, and that the excise duty payable on the blend, the crude oil or condensate will be payable at a rate equal to either the diesel rate or the leaded petrol rate, depending upon the composition of the petroleum product. Fourthly, there will be amendments to the Excise Act 1901 to provide that, where either blended petroleum products or crude oil are duty paid at the rate applicable to diesel fuel and where the products are for use in an eligible manner for the purposes of the diesel fuel rebate scheme, then a rebate of duty under that scheme is payable. Finally, amendments to the Excise Act 1901 will allow payments to certain producers of naphtha from oil shale where certain conditions have been met. These payments are intended to encourage the demonstration of new oil shale processing technologies, recognising that full-scale commercial development needs to take place on its economic merits. Financial impact statement Amendments to the diesel fuel rebate the scheme, other than the imposition of an administration charge-the amendments to the DFRS are expected to result in the following savings: $3.9 milliop. in financial year 199394; $15.8 million in financial year 1994-95; and $16.9 million in financial year 1995-96. Amendments in respect of microbreweriesthe amendments to ensure that beer produced with the assistance of commercial facilities and equipment is subject to both customs control and excise duty is expected to generate revenue as follows: $109,000 in financial year 1993-94; and $200,000 in financial year 1994-95. Amendments in respect of petroleum substitution-the amendments addressing the problems associated with the blending of petroleum products is expected to generate revenue as follows:. $14 million in financial year 1993-94; $19.5 million in financial year 199495; and $19.5 million in financial year 199596. Amendments in respect of certain naphtha producers-the payments to certain naphtha producers are not expected to have any financial impact before the 1996-97 financial year because of the fact that production using the new process is unlikely to commence before that period. This particular bill deals with the first of those points: that is, the imposition of an administration charge on certain applications for rebate of excise duty paid in respect of diesel fuel. Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: NATIONAL HEATH AMENDMENT
text: Calwell-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health) (6.22 p.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. This bill proposes an amendment to the National Health Act 1953 to Complement amendments made last year to the nursing home benefit payments scheme by the National Health Amendment Act 1992. This bill is related to the Nursing Home Charge (Imposition) Bill 1993 and should be read in conjuncis subject to tion with that bill. The National Health Amendment Act 1992 was enacted to address inequities in the recovery of unspent Commonwealth nursing home benefit when a nursing home is sold. These problems flowed from a quirk in the legislation which meant that amounts of unspent benefit were not legally characterised as debts to the Commonwealth. Where a nursing home proprietor accrued a liability and sold the nursing home, that vendor could not be pursued for the 'money after the sale. The purchaser became liable for that 'amount. Whilst the Commonwealth nevertheless had a statutory duty to recover such amounts, they could be recovered only via an offset or ongoing negative fee loading to the approved daily nursing home fee and, by extension, the amount of Commonwealth benefit payable each month. This sometimes resulted in the purchaser acquiring a home subject to a liability accrued by a former proprietor. Although the industry was well aware of these arrangements and usually made appropriate provisions in contracts of sale, problems still occurred. The National Health Amendment Act 1992 addressed this situation by providing that amounts of unspent benefit were characterised as debts recoverable from the vendor on sale. n contained a number of key measures to support its purpose, including a requirement for vendors to give 90 days notice of a sale. This period of notice enables the vendor's claims for Commonwealth benefit, books and records t() be examined so that, prior to completion of the sale, a fair estimate of any overpayment can be made. However, these changes only apply prospectively, applying to benefits paid after the commencement of the National Health Amendment Act 1992 on 1 July 1993. Benefits paid prior to the commencement of that act are not s'ubject to its provisions and the pre"existing system of recovery by fee loading continues to apply in respect of benefits paid up to 30 June 1993. The two bills tabled forconsideration in the current sittings together allow for the debt recovery measures to extend prior to 1 July 1993. The Nursing Home Charge (Imposition) Bill 1993 imposes a charge on the vendor of a nursing home on sale equal to the amount of any benefit unspent by the nursing home up to 30 June 1993. The National Health Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993 sets out the administrative arrangements for the collection and recovery of such amounts from the vendor on sale of a nursing home. This latter bill also provides that where the Commonwealth holds moneys in trust for the benefit of the vendor pending completion of an investigation of the nursing home accounts, and on completion it is found that money is repayable to the vendor, the Commonwealth is liable to pay interest at commercial ra-es on the amount repayable. These measures complement those in the National Health Amendment Act 1992. They provide, effectively, that amounts of unspent b"nefit paid prior to the recent prospective amendments are recoverable from the vendor as debts on sale. The National Health Amendment Act 1992 received the support of both the nursing home industry and the coalition, as expressed in this House by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) and in the Senate by Senators Newman and Patterson. Those who spoke did, however, express a·concem, shared by the industry and the government alike, that there was a need for those measures to be applied prior to 1 July 1993. The National Health Amendment Act (No. 3) 1993 addresses that need by complementing the National Health Amendment Act 1992 to augment the protection already given to the rights of purchasers of homes, provide a more equitable system and enable the Commonwealth to recover unspent moneys in a more timely manner. I commend the bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill. Debate (on motion by Mr Ronaldson) adjourned. Title: NURSING HOME CHARGE
text: Calwell-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health) (6.27 p.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. BOUNTY (SHIPS) AMENDMENT BILL Consideration resumed from 27 September. Second Reading  tary to the Mi-ister for Defence) (6.29 p.m.) - I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill 1993 proposes amendments to the Bounty (Ships) Act 1989 which implement the government's election commitment announced by the Prime Minister (Mr - eating) on 24 February 1993 to extend the shipbuilding bounty in line with general manufacturing tariffs so that it is progressively reduced from the current 10 per cent. to five per cent by July 1996. The proposed amendments replace the existing bounty rates with the new rates for the period 1993-94 to 1996-97. The proposed new rates correspond with the tariff reductions set down in the government's statement 'Building a Competitive Australia' of 12 March 1991. Rather than the more rapid phase down and termination of the bounty by 1 July 1995 set down in the current act, the new rates proposed are nine per cent for 1993-94, eight per cent for 1994-95, seven per cent for 1995-96 and five per cent. for 1996-97. The government's decision on bounty rates was made after consultation between the government and the Australian Shipbuilders Association. Furthedssues raised by the association relating to the administration of the scheme, including the provisions to apply at the end of the scheme and the future of the scheme beyond July 1997, will also be considered by this government. The shipbuilding industry has changed from a dying industry in the 1970s when the industry was characterised by industrial unrest, high levels of government support and traditional production of conventional ships for what was then a declining world market to one of Australia's manufacturing successes. Now Australian builders are leading their competitors in the fast ferry sector and luxury yachts, but the rest of the world is catching up fast. Substantial progress toward becoming a 1993 viable, export orientated manufacturing sector has been made despite the reducing levels of bounty. Now the industry is a multimillion dollar export earner specialising in innovative products for niche markets. Some are already recognised as world leaders due to their approach to design and product techriology. Shipbuilders now are concentrating on vessels such as passenger and vehicular ferries, luxury motor yachts, offshore supply vessels, tugs and small trading vessels. The government recognises the problems that could result from premature phasing out of assistance and proposes to extend the bounty in line with general manufacturing tariffs. The more gradual reduction in the bounty rate will sustain the competitive gains made by the industry. The period of the new bounty regime promises years of strong export growth coupled with increased employment as the industry gears up to meet international competition. To maintain a leading position builders have to continue to produce world-beating designs and technology in new sectors. This will present major challenges in re-equipping to build bigger ships, in financing larger orders and in funding bigger operations generally. Given their success so far, we believe shipbuilders deserve at least the same support from government that other Australian manufacturers get while they tackle these challenges. Financial impact statement The measures contained in this bill are expected to result in a net cost to outlays as follows: $6.6 million in financial year 1993-94, $6 million in financial year 199.4-95, $16.2 million in financial year 1995-96, and $15 n:tillion in financial year 1996-97. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the bill. Debate (on motion by Mr Ronaldson) adjourned. Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: SALES TAX ASSESSMENT
text: These bills will be known in history as the Treasurer resignation bills or maybe even the Dawkins resignation bills. It was over these bills at press conference last week that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) flagged his private desire to resign from the position of Treasurer because of the lack of support in.his own caucus and indeed in the cabinet for his budget and for his budget strategy. Both of those things have been little short of a: catastrophe for the Australian Labor Party, for the re-elected Labor government, for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and above all for the Treasurer. These bills have proved necessary because the government's budget strategy involved something that we so often get from the Australian Labor Party:' an attempt to make short cuts. Basically what the government proposed in the original omnibus tax bill was to lump together a whole series of tax increases-a betrayal bill it is sometimes being called-in order to try to spook the Senate into supporting all,of them rather than trying to amend the bill and oppose some aspects of the legislation. The genesis of this strategy was a view that the Treasurer had, and no doubt the Prime Minister as well, that since the omnibus bill was a bill imposing tax it could not be amended by the Senate and therefore, the go- ' ' vernment would be able to push through. what would have to be not only the most deceitful but also some of the most regressive taxation measures known in Australian political history. Not long after the government unveiled the original omnibus bill, it realised that it could not continue to maintain the argument that the bill could not be amended. If it maintained that argument, then it would be conceding, in effect, that the bill would be unconstitutional because it imposed more than one tax measure. , The government then said, 'We are sticking with this omnibus tax bill. It is constitutional. it is a fundamental part'-honourable members should remember that-'of the government's budget strategy. We are not going to waiver, we are going to stand by this omnibus tax bill, but you can try to amend it if you like'. That was the first albeit rather minor backdown. As a result of legal advice the coalition his received that the bill not orily imposed a tax but also imposed several taxes, the coalition argued that the omnibus tax bill was unconstitutional. If the bill were passed,' then it would be subject to challenge in the High Court and, as a resu-t of that, the government would have to go back to the drawing board with its budget. So the coalition referred the bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. One of the more interesting developments in this parliament since the last federal election was the way the Senate legal and constitutional affairs committee responded to that bill. ' Given the history of the way the Labor Party works, one would think that Labor Party members on that Senate committee would simply put a tick in the box marked 'Labor' and make sure that they supported the position of the Treasurer: that the bill was perfect1y constitutional, which was beyond any reasonable doubt, and that it should be supported by the parliament. But, to their everlasting credit, Labor members of the committee joined the coalition members in arguing that the bill introduced by the government raised a very serious risk of it being unconstiincrease tutional. The judgment by the Senate legal and constitutional affairs committee undid this element of the Treasurer's budget strategy. That committee-in particular Labor members of the committee-humiliated the Tr-surer to such an extent that he turned on his own caucus, turned on Labor members of the Senate committee, denounced them, and started speculating on his own resignation. Given that the Treasurer had argued for five solid weeks in the face of all the legal evidence that could be mustered that the omnibus tax bill was constitutional and then found at the end of those five weeks that even the Labor Party senators were not prepared to support that proposition, he should have done the honourable thing: he should have taken his own advice and resigned from the position of Treasurer of Australia because of the instability and the uncertainty that. he had created in this country through not only the budget measures introduced in his budget but also the way he - ctically tried to handle that budget. The children of that particular omnibus tax bill are these eight bills which are before the House' tonight. I believe it is very important when we consider all of the budget shenanigans of the Labor Party to understand one simple thing: this is the Keating strategy. Do honourable members .remember the Treasurer's immortal words which he refused to deny when given the opportunity during question time yesterday? He said, 'I am prepared to be the bunny for Keating'. Indeed he was. The great Keating strategy is to promise massive tax cuts which would not have to be funded by increases in indirect taxes. He said, 'We caq give you massive tax cuts and you will never get a GST to fund them. We ;will never increase indirect taxes-. All of those promises, followed by an election victory based on those promises, left the government and Mr Dawkins with an unholy mess. They could not fund the income tax cuts without resorting to either indirect tax increases or spending cuts. They had to do one or the other. The proposition that had been put at the election that the government could increase spending, that it would not indirect taxes and that it would provide income tax cuts turned out to be just what opposition members pointed out was the case at the time of the .last election - little short of a fraud. In the end the Treasurer was left to pick up the pieces of this mess. He produced a budget which was a betrayal of the Australian electorate not only by increasing indirect taxes-1 think it is very important that people rememberthis-but also by increasing the revenue from indirect taxes to the extent that revenue in 1996-97 from sales taxes, payroll taxes and fuel excise-all the taxes the coalition was going to abolish and replace with a GSTwould be the equivalent of the revenue by that year that the Commonwealth would have obtained from the GST. I think that is a very cruel and a very sad irony. It underlines the way' that the Labor Party, in particular the Prime Minister, simply betrayed the Australian electorate at the last election. They will never forgive him for that. The bills before the House are therefore broken up versions of that original omnibus tax bill-the bill of betrayal-and they therefore incotporate many aspects of that betrayal. These bills are also highly aggressive in their impact. The increases in sales tax are borne disproportionately by low income Australians. The rich can happily bear and pay what constitutes a 10 per cent-one percentage point-increase in sales tax on something like toothpaste. The people who have done very well in the last 10 years under a Labor government-the richest 10 per cent of 'the population who have got massively richercan easily pay that. But what about low income Australians? The 10 percent of Australians on the lowest incomes in the last decade have seen their incomes decline by 10 per cent in the last 10 years. These are the people who have to bear the brunt of the burden of the increases in' sales tax; the increase in sales tax on wine, if they are wine drinkers; and, indirectly, the increases in taxes such as fringe benefits tax which business simply passes on in the form of higher prices. These measures are highly regressive. The government stands condemned for introducing measures which are so regressive. For the Labor Party to have spent the last 101 years since it was founded rushing around Australia trying to convince people that the Labor Party is the party of the battler and to have come to this parliament with this bunch of bills which are a penalty on low income Australians is one of the cruellest ironies of all. These bills are also job destroying bills. We have. one million unemployed people in Australia. One would think that in this chamber there would be an overwhelming priority to do things to create jobs for those people. One would think that was a logical and overwhelming priority; But is it in these bills? To take the example of the wine industry, these bills increase the tax burden on that export oriented, job creating industry by 55 per cent. How many morejobs will we create in the wine industry if we whack up taxes by 55 per cent? How many more jobs will we create in industry in general in this q>untry if we whack up sales taxes which are-at least in their initial stage-taxes on business, increasing the costs of running businesses and, in tum, making it more expensive for businesses to employ people? How many more export orders will we get in this country, and therefore jobs from exports, by increasing tax on exports? That is what these bills before the House tonight do. The bills are a betrayal; the bills are sive in their effect. They are disproportionately damaging to low income Australians. The bills are job destroying. According to the New South Wales Chamber of Manufactures, these bills, plus the fuel excise which is in separate legislation, will basically destroy around 50,000 jobs in this country. I put it. to the House that, if the government had announced before the last election that this package of bills would be introduced were Labor to be re-elected, Labor would have lost the election by a landslide. Why did it not have the decency, the honour and the integrity to tell Australians that this was what it planned· to do after the election? I think that. will perhaps rest as one of the strongest and saddest indictments of the Keating government. In any case, the budget process, as members are well aware and as these bills illustrate only too clearly, has been little more than a shambles. As a result of that, in relation to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.1) 1993, I move: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the 'following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the - ouse: (1) c()ndemns the Government for including in this Bill a measure which subjects the accrued leave entitlements of Australian workers to retrospective increases in taxation; (2) calls on the Government to abandon its proposal to impose a retrospective increase in taxation on accrued lea'{e lump sums; and (3) is of the opinion that the proposals in the Bill ought to have been put forward as four separate Bills: one dealing with Fringe Benefits Tax, a second dealing with the taxation of accrued leave lump sums, a third dealing with the taxation of Credit Unions, and a fourth dealing with the Medicare threshold". The Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.1) 1993, which is the only one I can move an amendment to in the context of the way the Labor Party has structured this debate, incorporates a whole range of different measures and imposes a whole range of different taxes. Very soon the coalition will be releasing legal opinion establishing that this bill is regresunconstitutional. In the Senate we will be once again referring this bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I see no reason whatsoever why the parliament. should support a bill which is of doubtful constitutionality. Indeed, in our view, it is unconstitutional. The' government should break this bill up into its component parts so that the question of whether it is constitutional or not may be put beyonq any reasonable doubt. If the government were prepared to do that in relation to this bill.and the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.2) 1993, then that whole. spectre of a High Court challenge hanging over the budget would simply disappear. Having withdrawn the omnibus tax bill, why the Treasurer has moved to introduce the first two bills in this package of bills which have all the same constitutional faults as the original omnibus tax bill is· beyond me. Why the government would want to do that, I simply cannot understand. If the government is responsible, why not try to make matters simple, clear and beyond controversy? That is what it should do. As I mentioned in my amendment, it should also delete the retrospective elements of the leave tax increase. I urge the government to do that. We shall be moving that amendment in another place where we will actually be allowed to move the amendment more formally. I hope it succeeds in that place. In relation to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.3) 1993, we will not have the opportunity to mqve the amendment in. the chamber tonight because of the way the Labor Party has constructed this debate. We regard that as completely undemocratic. The fact is that we will in another place be moving an amendment to break the linkage between the change to the income tax cuts schedules and the passage of the sates tax bills which are part of this package. If the government is committed to changing the schedule for the income tax cuts-it is committed to providing income tax cuts by Christmas-why on earth would it make it difficult for the parliament to approve income tax cuts by Christmas? On this side of the House, we want people to get income tax cuts by Christmas. On this side of the House, we want to make sure the parliament can easily provide those income tax cuts. The government is insincere in its claim that it wants to provide income tax cuts by Ch'ristmas. The way the government is drafting legislation,and the way it has drafted this bill, makes it more difficult-not easierfor the parliament to provide income tax cuts to Australians for Christmas. We will have the amendment incorporated in Hansard here, but we will be moving the amendment in another place to destroy the link between the .passage of this bill, the implementation of these measures and the passage of the sales tax bills. In relation to the sales tax bills, I reiterate the view that we have argued since 19 August this year that we will not be supporting the increases in the sales tax. Again, as we will not be able to move that amendment here today, we will just have to incorporate it in Hansard. We will not be supporting the increase in the sales tax and we will not be supporting the 55 per cent increase in tax on the wine industry. We will be standing in opposition to those things. In doing so, the coalition, and the coalition alone, will be standing up for Australians. There are a lot of political parties nowadays in the parliament of Australia: the Liberal and National parties, the Labor Party, the Greens and the Australian Democrats. There is also Senator Harradine. The unequivocal support for the people of Australia comes from the Liberal and National parties. We are the parties opposing the increase in the wine tax, the increase in the sales tax, the retrospective imposition of a higher tax on annual leave and increases in fuel excise. We stand alone in our public opposition to those things. If the government wants a quick passage for its budget-the Prime Minister and the Treasurer say they do-it can do two or three simple things. First, it can break up the two bills in this package which are clearly unconstitutional so that their constitutionality is put . beyond doubt. Secondly, it can recognise that the vast majority of Australians, including the coalition, is opposed to increases in sales tax, ftiel excise and wine tax and the retrospective tax on annual leave. It can delete those measures and still increase spending but reduce the growth in government spending in order to finance the 1112 per cent of revenue that would be affected by those measures being deleted from the budget. If the government takes those common sense steps, its budget will sail through the parliament. Stability will be restored to financial markets, confidence of some kind will be restored to business and, as a country, we will know where we are going as far as the budget is concerned. The debate about. the budget .will be completed tonight or tomorrow if the Prime Minister and the Treasurer take up the challenge that I issue to them tonight. If they make those changes to the budget, we will very happily allow all of the measures to pass through. Both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are going around Australia arguing that coalition members are opposing - he. budget, saying that we are vandals and wreckers and standing in the way of the Labor Party's budget. I want Australians to know-and this will not come as a surprise to them-that the Prime Minister, when he says that, is· not telling the truth. We are not opposing the budget. We' are not trying to block supply. We are simply saying that we will not support in the parliament Ilh per cent of the government's total revenue measures. We will not vote for Ph per cent of the government's reVenue measures, but if it accepts the common sense approach and abandons those silly, regressive, damaging and dishonest measures this budget' will sail through. I believe that that is the obvious and common sense thing for the government to do. Opposition members will not sit quietly on this side of the House and have the Prime Minister in particular, day after day- claiming that we are wrecking his dear, beloved budget or that we are standing in the way of tax cuts by Christmas. 'Tax cuts by Christmas' is the new Labor Party line. Government members do not tell people about the tax increases by Christmas. They do not tell people about the increases in sales tax and fuel excise, the on wine, the retrospective tax on lump sums. They do not tell people that they have abandoned $5 billion worth of income tax cuts. Government members do not tell people any of that, but say that the coalition is standing in the way of tax cuts by Christmas. Opposition members are standing in the way of no such thing. Australians will be guaranteed their tax cuts by Christmas if the Prime Minister and the Treasurer simply have the decency to abandon the most regressive of their proposals, which are incorporated in legislation, as' well as the increase in fuel excise, and if they have the decency to break the link in the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.3) 1993 between the passage of the worse of these sales tax measures and the income tax cuts. I am sorry that those on this side of the House will not have more time to debate these bills. The previous tax omnibus bill was also guillotined through the parliament and we had very little opportunity to say much about that. I am sorry that we will not be able to move our amendments in this chamber. It just shows how Rafferty'S rules apply here because the Labor Party has complete control of the numbers in the House. But we will move our amendments in the Senate, and I am confident that they will be carried.
