Speaker: Mr ELLIOTT
Title: SALES TAX ASSESSMENT
text: Parramatta) (8.25 p.m.)From listening to the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) 'speak in the debate on these taxa_tion bills tonight, we get the impression that opposition members are not going to be obstructionist, that they are all clear in their hearts as they desperately want people to get their tax cuts by Christmas, and they will do everything possible to enable that to occur. Of course, nothing could be further from the - truth. As the honourable member for Mayo well knows, ever since the election in March that the opposition did not believe it could lose it has set out on a course of obtax struction: The opposition has set out to do everything it can to jeopardise economic recovery in Australia, and has basically been determined to create as much uncertainty as possible in the economy and amongst investors in the international community. To this extent, the opposition has used the numbers situation in the Senate to try to advance that cause. Nothing that has been said by the honourable member for Mayo tonight alters that basic fact. Indeed, we even have the suggestion that we are going to go this through another Senate committee referral process in the hope the opposition might be able to continue to delay the implementation of the government's budget measures and, by direct implication, therefore jeopardise the tax cuts that Australians have due to them on 15 November. Unless these deficit reduction measures are passed tonight and then passed by the Senate, the Australian Taxation Office has made it clear that it cannot take the steps to implement the personal tax cut arrangements that are due on 15 November. The tax office has made clear that the administrative arrangements need to be settled by no later than 21 October if the tax cuts are to be forthcoming in the middle of November. No amount of humbug by the opposition can alter those basic tenets. This brings us to the basic point of what these measures are designed to achieve. Why is it important to have a deficit reduction package as part of the 1993 budget, and how crucial is it to economic recovery, economic stability and economic growth? If one looks around the world, it is evident that it is important for Australia to be able to outline a comprehensive deficit reduction plan in the medium term so as to ensure businesses and investors from here and abroad can be confident about Australia's economic position. All around the world, countries are trying to grapple with the deficit problem and how deficits can be brought back into line. There was a major debate in the United States Congress about a package that reduces its deficit to something over three per cent of gross domestic product, and they regard three per cent as a significant achievement. In Australia, by adopting a range of measures in this particular budget, we have a strategy to reduce our deficit to 1.1 per cent of GDP by 1996-97. That is very important. Why is it very important? The answer is that it provides scope over time to encourage further private sector investment in Australia and therefore sustain the economic recovery so vital to the creation of jobs. They are the issues that really matter. For the honourable member for Mayo, as the shadow Treasurer, to say, 'We will pass the tax cuts, but we do not want to deal with the revenue measures that are contained in the budget', is grossly irresponsible. It goes back to the sort of thing we saw delivered from the opposition in the lead-up to the election and in its performance in government. Indeed, it is a reflection of its policies today. Opposition members no longer believe in the GST, we are told. We do not really know what they believe in any more. There has been no articulation by the honourable member for Mayo of what they believe in any way, shape or form. We do know that opposition members have tried their level best to ensure that a comprehensive deficit reduction plan, as outlined by the government, cannot be put into effect. That view cannot be sustained. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) are perfectly responsible in maintaining that the opposition, by adopting this tactic of obstruction and delay, is only jeopardising the economic recovery, the economic certainty of financial markets and also the budget stability that is needed over the next three to four years. It is worth noting as well what the benefits of getting that deficit reduction plan mean. They mean that the economic growth of 2.6 per cent we have now-the fastest in the OECD-can be sustained. They mean that the short-term stimulus from public sector spending outlined in this budget will gradually be taken up in further years by private sector investment. They mean that we can maintain the low inflationary setting that has been created by the government. They mean that we can maintain the low interest rate regime that applies, and they will give encouragement to economic recovery as well. The alternative to that is to say that it does not matter what happens to interest rates; it does not matter what happens to inflation. Basically, that seems to be where the opposition is coming from on this issue today, and that is clearly unacceptable. The Governor of the Reserve Bank has already pointed out that if there is not some certainty about the budget process then eventually the Reserve Bank could be forced to take action in relation to interest rates. Already, the dollar has lost ground against international currencies because of that uncertainty. Over the last couple of weeks, I was part of a .parliamentary delegation to Germany. In Germany, where there is significant intereSt in trade with Australia, people were talking about this issue: what was going to happen to the budget; :what was the Senate doing; what was the rationale behind it all. There is international concern about a process where it is not clear what sort of policy the opposition actually has. Even more importantly, there is a concern that the signal going out internationally might create doubts in the minds of potential investors or currency markets. That is what we are dealing with here. This is not some political game.of a partisan nature that enables the opposition to refer anything it likes to a Senate committee and then seek further references each time matters go back to the Senate. This is a time to decide whether or not the national interest counts. It is a time for us to decide whether or not economic recovery really. matters. If it does, and if we are genuine about wanting to get both growth and jobs, then getting the budget package passed is important. It should be a priority, not just for the government of the day but for the parliament of the day, if it is genuinely concerned about Australia's future. That is what we are dealing with in the package of bills that has come back before us tonight. The government has formulated a number of important responses to the findings of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. First of all, it has rejected the notion that the original package, the omnibus bill, was unconstitutional. That has not been tested. The only place where that can be tested is in the High Court. No-one else has the authority to pass judgment on that issue. The government has announced that it is prepared to put forward a test case bill that can be referred to the High Court for adjudication if that is the course that people want to follow. That is not because the government has had any advice to suggest that that is the case; it is a recognition of what the Senate committee has said and to allay those concerns. It does not alter the basic tenet on which the bills before us tonight are based. The opposition is trying to undo the 1993 budget process by adopting a course of action which would inevitably create a situation where people are denied tax cuts-tax cuts that are important because they are part of the ongoing economic stimulus to the economy. Alternatively, the opposition is simply out to create mayhem for mayhem's sake. Neither of those situations constitutes legitimate action on the part of an opposition in a federal parliament-not for a party claiming to have any degree of responsibility in its approach. It is important to recognise that, overall, Australia compares very favourably to other countries as far as taxation is concerned. In the course of the last four or five years, there have been gradual changes to income tax arrangements to bring them into line and make them more competitive with other countries. The government has also fulfilled its commitment to reducing the company tax rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent. Amongst other things, we have introduced dividend imputation. All these measures were designed to make us more internationally competitive. With the opening up of the Australian economy, those measures created more certainty and more opportunities to establish us as an international trading nation. When we talk to people around the world about the issues that matter to a trading nation, they point to things such as stability, a degree of predictability about the political process, and not having this sort. of log jam of Senate obstructionism. From that point of view, Australia has always been regarded as a very safe and secure place. However, over recent years, the opposition has had a desperate desire to talk down economic recovery. It has tried its level best to set a course of action that denies the opportunity for economic recovery and stability to occur. 1 do not believe the people of Australia can allow that to occur. This government has started the trend towards growth-a growth to date of 2.6 per cent.· We started a positive trend in stimulating the economy through the implementation of the One Nation policy and last year's. budget. We have recognised the need to change company tax arrangements by reducing the company tax rate to 33 per cent, and by introducing measures relating to depreciation allowances, investment allowances, and so on. These are all designed to encourage private sector investment. The measures contained in the package before the House tonight add to that position because they bring forward tax cuts for ordinary income earners that were originally promised to come into effect from July next year. They bring them forward by seven months to take effect fromS November because we recognise that they will advance the contribution of households to national economic recovery. These cuts are going to the people of m'iddle Australia and giving them the benefits of tax reform because previous tax cuts have related to either the lower end or the top end of the income scale. It is generally recognised that middle income earners are the. group in line for tax cuts this particular time. Other measures that the opposition is trying to knock over in this House tonight include the $3a week rebate for low income earners. Although the opposition has been asking questions about low income earners, when it is in a position to do something constructive it seeks to jeopardise this measure. The honourable member for Mayo said that the opposition wanted to see personal income tax cuts passed on and.paid before Christmas. If that is what the honourable member wants to ensure, the simple answer is to pass the bills before the House-pass'therri expeditiously-and ensure that his colleagues hi the Senate do not employ the stalling devices that have become part and parcel of Senate processes in recent times: They should get on with the job of getting the budget passed and allowing the community the tax cuts to which they are entitled from the middle of November. I would like to mention some of the other elements of the budget process and what they mean in relation to the deficit reduction plan. In the' 1992 period, because of the sluggish nature of economic circumstances', we recognised the need for public sector stimulus. The govetnment has been attempting to meet that need for the last two years as evidenced by this year's deficit of $16 billion. While that deficit represents only a very small percentage of gross domestie product-about 3.8 per cent-we recognise that public sector borrowing requirements over the next two to three years is something we will need to watch. That is why this package of bills not only deals with measures relating to expenditure but also to revenue. We could not have a taxation deficit reduction bill without being cognisant of those two issues. ' That is what the opposition is saying does not matter. Members of the opposition are basically saying that they do not care about the deficit reduction bill; they think that we can simply have the expenditure side of the budget. The tax measures and revenue measilres which we have introduced are something which they want nothing to do with. It is fine for the opposition to take that approach but what should be borne in mind is that this is the same opposition that went to the polls last March saying that there should be cuts of over $10 billion in outlays to the community. The opposition was going to wreak havoc on, the community at large. It was going to take steps to ensure that many of the ordinary services that people need and deserve would be devastated by its approach. Now it is saying that the deficit reduction package that the government has introduced-a responsible and sustainable measure-should not be applied. ' This package of bills is crucial. It is important because it allows the government to give effect to both the revenue and expenditure side of the budget. In addition, because the question of constitutionality has been raised in the Senate, there should be an opportunity for a couple of the measures to be the subject of a' test case, if that is what is desired. We have heard all the nonsense from the oppositi()n about obtaining legal opinion after legal opinion, which it claims demonstrates and proves-those were the words used-the unconstitutionality' of the package of bills previously introduced by the Treasurer. Here is the opportunity .to have the matter tested,. All the advice that the government has received suggests that it is a highly debatable point. The committee made two basic points about the potential invalidity of the bills. The first is that any increase in the formal rate of tax is an imposition of tax. This view draws an illogical conclusion between a rate increase and an enlargement of a tax base. The second point is that any increase in liability to taxation is an imposition of tax. If this argument is accepted, then most of the tax laws passed in the last 50 years are also invalid. It is not accepted that the strategy and the opinion that the opposition has kept on advancing has been applicable to processes followed not just by this government but by the previous· government in the way it has introduced and processed tax measures. But we are told that it has somehow changed dramatically as a result of the 1993 budget. The opposition claims to have further legal opinion to demonstrate the invalidity and illegality of these measures. If that is the case, the opposition can use Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.2) to test those elements. That is why the Treasurer has implemented that strategy. It has been done in such a way that it does not upset the fundamental integrity of what is required in getting the budget through, getting the deficit reduction strategy adopted and restoring certainty to the Australian community about the 1993 budget. It is not healthy to have a situation created where people llll over the world are not sure whether or riot the 1993 budget is valid. When we look at the statistics as to what the deficit .reduction plan actually means to the Australian .economy, we find that people connected with economic advice around the world say, . 'We would love to get to a situation where our budget deficit is one per cent of GDP·. Most countries say that they do not have a hope in Hades of achieving that result. 1I have referred to the example with regard to the United States. We have provided short-tenn fiscal stimulus to the economy through the 1993 budget, and we also have a comprehensive medium-tenn strategy that outlines measures on the revenue side to get the deficit reduction down to one per cent of GDP by 1996-97. We have a comprehensive strategy which outlines a mechanism to ensure that economic growth can be sustained, firstly, through public sector investment and then increasingly through the private sector investment. We have a competitive tax· regime in both the company and personal income tax areas. Our economic growth is faster than anywhere else in the world. We have the lowest inflation rate for 20 years, together with the lowest interest rates for over 20 years. We have a sustainable low inflation outlook, unlike some European countries that are quite worried about inflation taking off, notwithstanding their recessionary conditions and deficits. We are not in that situation. Australia is in a situation where it can mOve forward as an internationally competitive trading nation and create both the economic activity and, in tum, the jobs that are vital to get Australians over their difficulties. We have had a very painful recession. What is the opposition's approach to that comprehensive strategy? It says, 'We will try to create as .much difficulty and uncertainty as we can about the 1993 budget'. What are the matters of principle on which the opposition takes that action? It does not have any matters of principle. The opposition has an opinion of some description which says that some of these tax measures might be unconstitutional because of the way in w-ich they have been packaged. The bills before the House tonight remove that uncertainty. The opposition has its chance to pass the bills and to test the measures that the Treasurer has provided in Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.2). As a result, everyone can be clear that the convention and practice that has been followed in the way many of these ipdirect tax revenue arrangements have been worked out over a long period of time-not just in the 1993 budgetcan be given effect. Thus, we can have an end to this spectacle of doubt being created around the world about the budget. It is important that we recognise the priority that should be given to this matter. The Senate should not continue to be obstructionist. It is high time that the opposition worked in . the national interest rather than in some partisan political interest, because what We need is. sustainable and stable economic recovery. That should be. the objective of everyone in the parliament. I am sure it is the objective of the people of Australia ..

Speaker: Mr WILLIAMS
Title: SALES TAX ASSESSMENT
text: Tangney) (8.45 p.m.)Mr Deputy Speaker, you have given me the call as the member for Tangney. The seat is named after Dame Dorothy Tangney. I take the opportunity to note quickly three anniversaries relating to her parliamentary career. The 50th anniversary of her first election to the Senate, as the first woman member, was on 21 August. The 50th anniversary of her first sitting in the Senate was on 23 September-last Thursday. The 50th anniversary of her inaugural speech was 24 September-last Friday. I turn to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.1) anQ cognate bills, the subject of this unjustifiably foreshortened debate. This debate is occurring because the government sought to play politicS with the constitution and got caught out. The government's problems arise out of section 55 of the constitution, an important provision relevant to revenue measures. Section 55 provides in effect that laws imposing taxation shall deal only with the imposition of taxation. The section also provides that laws imposing taxation shall deal with one subject of taxation only. The section treats each of customs duties and excise duties in effect as one subject. The reason for the existence of section 55 is to be found in section 53. This provides that a proposed law imposing taxation shall not originate in the Senate. Under the section, the Senate may not amend a proposed law imposing taxation. Section 55 provides protection to - he Senate in light of the restrictions in section 53. This House is prevented from tacking extraneous provisions to laws imposing taxation which the Senate may not amend. Section 55 also prevents this House from sending to the Senate a bill for the imposition of taxation in respect of a number of unrelated subjects when the Senate would, by virtue of section 53, be unable to amend the bill by approving some provisions and rejecting others. '. . Those. provisions set out a carefully constructed arrangement designed to ensure that each proposal for the imposition of taxation can be considered independently. They provide in relation to the arrangement protection of the .Senate against this House and protection of both this House and the Senate against the executive. It is consistent with that constitutional arrangement that the parliamentary practice has developed of enacting a tax act separately from an assessment act. The tax act imposes taxation and is, therefore, subject to the requirements of sections 53 and 55. The assessment act provides for assessment and collection of taxation and, therefore, deals with taxation. But it does not impose taxation and, accordingly, is not subject to the requirements of the sections. What the government first sought· to do with its original bill was not consistept with past practice or with constitutional arrangements, In the omnibus bill it contemplated, among a range of proposals, by clause 12 increasing the rate of tax under the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986; by clauses 70, 71' and 72 increasing the rate of tax lll1der the Income Tax Rates Act 1986; and by clause 85 increasing levies under the Medicare Levy Act 1986. Fringe benefits tax, income tax and the Medicare levy are plainly different subjects of taxation. If these proposed, clauses would impose taxation, the bill would breach section 55 of the constitution. . In introducing the original bill, the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) offered no reason for the omnibus treatment. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) insisted that the bill was a package which had to be accepted or rejected as a whole-the Senate could not 'cherry pick'. The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) confidently asserted on 23 August 1993 that there was no constitutional difficulty with the bill. In the Senate, with refreshing frankness, Senator Gareth Evans eventually stated on 1 September 1993 that the bill was a 'new precedent that is being created to bring together revenue measures of this kind in a particular way'. A,preCedent has certainly been set, but it is not the one that Senator Gareth Evans referred to. We all know what happened. After the bill was guillotined through this House, the Senate on 31 August 1993 referred the bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. That committee received a number of legal opinions and heard from witnesses including a number of lawyers. The committee reported on 20 September. The day before that the Attorney-General stated that he was 'perfectly confident' that the bill was constitutional. In its report the committee concluded that the bill dealt with matters other than the imposition of taxation. The eight members of the committee, including four government members, unanimously took the view that 'there is a real risk which is significant that the High Court wouid' find the bill, if enacted, to be a law imposing taxation within' the meaning Of section 55 of the Constitution'. The committee' had before it written opinions of lawyers, including leading constitutional lawyers. They included Dr Colin Howard, now a barrister but formerly Hearn Professor 'of' Law at Melbourne University and a respected constitutional writer. Another opinion was from Mr David Jackson QC, a leader of the New South Wales and Queensland bars, a former Federal Court judge, and former chairman of the Constitutional Commission's Advisory Committee on the Australian Judicial System. Another was from Mr Stephen Charles QC, a leading Melbourne silk who is regularly briefed by the Commonwealth and its agencies. Each offered the view that the bill was unconstitutional. On the other side an opinion of Mr Denis Rose QC, Chief General ,Counsel, in the Office of General Counsel in the AttorneyGen,eral's Department, concluded that the bill was valid. Mr Rose was not asked to advise on the bill before it was introduced. The Treasurer's response to the committee report was rather unusual. He made grossly unfair imputations about the motives of the lawyers who had offered advice that the bill was unconstitutional. He also released a few well-chosen comments on the government members on the Senate committee. While maintaining the government position that the original bill was constitutional, the Treasurer did acknowledge that doubts about its legality had been raised. He announced on 21 September that the original bill would be divided into the eight bills currently under consideration. One ,of the new bills is the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.2) 1993 which is I referred to by the Treasurer as a test bill. This proposes to increase the rate of fringe benefits tax and to increase the rate of income tax on life insurance business conducted by friendly societies. As the government plainly intends, this appears to raise exactly the same question as to constitutional validity in relation to section 55 of the Constitution as the original bill did. ' Another of the' new bills, the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.1) 1993 is of particular interest. This provides for a new type of fringe benefit and imposes a tax on it in much the same way as se-tion 5 of the Fringe, Benefits Tax Act 1986 first imposed FBT., It also increases the rate of tax payable by credit unions. Although not acknowledged by the Treasurer, it appears to be in exactly the same situation as both the No.2 bill and the original bill in so fa,r as section 55 of the constitution is concerned. It also deals with other matters including amendments to deny income tax deductions to certain non-employees for car parking expenses and to effect amendments relating to payments in lieu of annual leave or long service leave. If the bill imposes taxation it contravenes section 55 in dealing with other matters so that the other matters would be of no effect. In the light of that it appears that there is not just one' test bill, but two test bills, and one of the teSt bills raises two different 'questions. ' The coalition has received formal legal advice that the new No. 1 bill and the No.2 bill are both in breach of section 55 of the cOlll?titution. On that basis it would be entirely appropriate, as proposed, for the Senate to refer those two bills to the Semite Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to consider their constitutional validity. The Treasurer has been quick to point out that in relation to the test bill there is time for the bill to be challenged before the High Court before most of its provisions come into operation on 1 April 1994. The government did not identify the new No. 1 bill as at constitutional risk. It has, therefore, not made any similar comment in relation to that bill. In fact, significant provisions of that bill come into operation earlier than 1 April 1994, including some provisions which apply from 1 July 1993. If the bill is unconstitutional it will presumably not be declared by the High Court to be invalid for some months after enactment. This would give rise to a great deal of uncertainty and confusion and, almost certainly, cost for taxpayers. The issue on whicn the legal opinions differ is not easily discussed in a truncated debate like this. It would do a disservice to the authors of the legal opinions to summarise the arguments to the extent necessary to refer to them in this debate. It is enough to say that the government view is put as a matter of form supported by authority. Those arguing the case for invalidity point to the substance and not the form and argue that the cases relied on by the government are not authority for the government's proposition. As between substance and form, I know where, I would want to rest my case. It is a sorry day when the government sees fit to embark on a precedent-setting, constitutionally risky exercise in relation to major revenue measures without first undertaking a careful examination of what is proposed to ensure that it is legal.

Speaker: Mr HICKS
Title: SALES TAX ASSESSMENT
text: There is a sense of deja vu in speaking on the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.1) and cognate bills as part of the budget mark 3 because 10 years ago, on 25 August 1983, as the member representing the Riverina and speaking on the budget I rose in this House and said: It is impossible to believe the lack of understanding of the Government in its decision to introduce an excise tax on fortified wines. That statement followed the rural policy speech of the previous Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in Griffith on 20 February 1983, who said: Labor has pledged not to impose a sales tax or an excise tax on wine. We will seek cooperation of the states to facilitate the establishment of grower regional councils. The Labor Government will examine the special problems faced by cooperative wineries and supplying growers. We now find ourselves back in the House with the government applying yet another tax on wine. Since those days in 1983 the wine industry has gone from strength to strength, not because of the taxes imposed by the government but because the wine industry has pushed along, despite the government, and become a major export industry, of which I am sure every Australian is very proud. Under these deficit reduction bills the government proposes increasing the present wine excise from 20 per cent to 31 per cent; in other words; an increase of 55 per cent. The government has caved into the pressure groups who say that wine should be taxed the same as beer and other spirits. But we all know that wine is not produced in the same way as spirits or beer. Wine is produced from a vintage crop that is produced only once a year and, therefore, should be treated differently. Why would the government increase taxes on one of the few industries that is providing such strong growth? Strangely, when the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) was asked about it, an AAP report quoted him thus: Federal Treasurer John Dawkins today described the sharp rise in the wine wholesale sales tax as an incentive for Australian wine makers. That is like the joke of putting a grasshopper on one's hands, "taking the legs off and saying, 'Jump', but it does not jump so one says, 'He's deaf'. The Treasurer told ABC radio, 'This won't hold back the wine industry'. I do not know where the Treasurer gets his information, but this increase in the wine excise will certainly hold back the wine industry, and" if I had more time. I would say more about that. The increase will have a dramatic effect in my electorate of Riverina. We have some famous wineries in my electorate, such as de Bortoli's. A lot of these wineries produce export wine which is known throughout the world for its quality and consistency. Some examples are MCWilliams Wines," Orlando Wines, Toorak Wines, Wilton Estate wiiles, Lillypilly wines from Leeton, Cranswick Estate, Miranda Wines, Rossetto Wines, West End wines and Riverina Wines.

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: Burke-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport arid Communications) (9.55 p.m.)-J move: That the bill be now read a second time. The bill amends four acts administered within the transport and communications portfolio. Most of the amendments are of a technical nature and represent a finetuning and clarifipenalties cation of provisions. The amendments do not introduce substantial new policy schemes. J will refer in tum to each of the acts being amended. Amendments of the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989 The amendment to the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989 will insert a new subsection 92(la) into the act which will allow Australia Post to operate a national change address scheme. The amendments are proposed following concerns raised by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances that exemptions to the secrecy provisions under regulation 20 of the Australian Postal Corporation regulations be included in primary legislation rather than delegated legislation. The bill will enable a customer's name and address to be disclosed where the customer consents in writing to the disclosure of their new address to a· person or organisation or class of organisation covered by the customer's consent. Australia Post is subject to the information privacy principles under the Privacy Act 1988. Accordingly, any information obtained by Australia Post as a consequence of the scheme must be handled in accordance with information privacy principles. Breaches of the disclosure provisions will be subject to section 70 of the Crimes Act 1914, that imposes a penalty of up to two to. years iniprisonme-t for Australia Post employees or contractors who breach their duty not to disclose information. A review of information disclosure for law enforcement purposes is being undertaken in consultation with federal, state and territory agencies. It is proposed, subject to the government's overall legislative priorities, to bring forward further amendments to section 92 in the budget sittings. Amendme'nts of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 The amendments to the Motor Vehicle Standards Act will correct some minor drafting errors in relation to the term 'road vehicle'. As well, in accordance with recent amendments to the Crimes Act, all monetary will be expressed in te- of penalty units. One penalty unit is currently valued at $100. Future amendments of the Crimes Act will increase the value of a penalty unit so that the penalties will reflect variations in current money values. The Motor Vehicle Standards Act is also being amended to provide for a penalty where conditions to import a non-standard vehiCle are breached. Typical conditions which may of be determined by the minister are, in the case of a vehicle imported for wrecking, that the vehicle will be dismantled or, in the case of a vehicle that is to .be used for transport in Australia, that the vehicle will be. made standard before it is supplied to the market. Amendments of the Radiocommunications Act 1992 The bill provides for amendments to the Radiocommunications Act 1992 which came into effect on 1 July 1993. The act replaces the Radiocommunications Act 1983 and provides for the implementation of government decisions for spectrum management refonn. The amendments are to correct a number of minor errors, such as typographical errors and incorrect references, in the 1992 act. As well, there are some amendments designed to overcome minor inconsistencies in the act. . . Amendments of the Telecommunications The amendment to section 209 of the Telecommunications Act 1991 makes it clear that Austel, the Australian Telecommunications Authority, can include conditions relating to law enforcement in class licences regulating supply of eligible services. The conditions provided for in the amendment relate in particular to requirements for suppliers of eligible services to consult with law enforcement agencies about new telecommunications technologies and to assist agencies in carrying out their law enforcement responsibilities. The provisions reflect similar conditions imposed on the licences of the three telecommunications carriers. The measures contained in this bill are expected to have no significant effect on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill and commend the bill to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr Sharp) adjourned. APPROPRIATION BILL (No.1) 1993-94 Second Reading Debate resumed from 27 September, on motion by Mr Dawkins: That the bill be now read a second time. upon which Dr Wooldridge had moved by way of amendment: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes: (1) the likelihood of foreshadowed amendments to the Budget; (2) the vacillations and confusion about the Budget; (3) the pernicious impact on low income Australians; (4) the failure to reduce unemployment; and (5) the continuing abrogation of responsibilities towards the long-term unemployed".

Speaker: Mr ATKINSON
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: Six weeks have passed since the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) brought down the budget. We are up to mark 3, and we are probably headed for mark 4. A number of discussions have taken place on where this budget is headed and on Act 1991 some of the implications for industries, particularly the wine industry. I want to look at employment in this country, and at the way that small businesses have been dealt with by this government. I draw the attentiol). of those honourable members who in the last couple of weeks have forgotten them to the first words that the Treasurer said when he introduced the budget to this House. He said: The greatest issue facing our nation is how to provide jobs for our fellow Australians. Too many are now out of work. Too many have been out of work for too long. The primary objective of this budget is jobs. He continued on to talk about jobs in the short, medium and long tenn. I would have thought on that basis that we would have seen a budget that was in the interest of Australian companies and Australian manufacturers. That is an area, in particular, in which I believe we can help to employ a substantial part of the unemployed group in our community if it is handled correctly in the policy mix that this government puts together. The latest issue of t4e Manufacturer$' Bulletin of the Chamber of Manufactures in New South Wales says: Almost 30,000 job opportunities Australia-wide will be lost as a result of increases in wholesale sales tax announced in the Federal Budget, according to the Chamber of Manufactures of New South Wales. Using its model of the Australian economy, the National Institute for Economic and Industry Research estimates that 3,000 job opportunities will go in the first year for every $100 million of extra sales tax revenue raised by the Government. Within five to seven years a total of 5,200 job opportunities will disappear for every $100 million of extra sales tax revenue. With the Government expecting to raise approximately $1 billion in sales tax this financial year, about 52,000 fewer jobs have been created by the year 2,000. That area concerns me a great deal, but I want to move to the overall attitudes and ways that this government has tried to talk about its interest in development. It is interesting to see that the Special Minister of State (Mr Walker) is at the table. He released yesterday a report entitled, Australia: your business location in Asia, which revealed that the Australian government encouraged Cathay Pacific to move a key telecommunication hub and data centre to Australia by waiving the sales tax. I think that is fairly significant.. I would like to look at a small industry that involves Australians working in small companies. Page 4.16 of the budget statements looks at the issue of microbrewers, and says: This change will mean that establishments known as 'micro breweries' which provide individual brewing facilities for consumers to brew their own beer, will be required to account for duty on beer produced on their premises. I find that fascinating. I have received a letter from Brew Kettle in Carnegie in Victoria, which states: Customs indicated to the investors in the stores they would not be subject to tax as commercial beer was not produced. A letter from the Amateur Brew on Premises Association of Australia, from Blackwood in South Australia, states: We understand that those who would like to see us out of business have consulted with the Customs Office regarding this legislation. As we have not had the luxury of consultation, we believe that only a thorough review of the enclosed information will ensure that a balanced argument is heard. Perhaps because it was a small item in the budget, they told me that at no stage had they been consulted by the minister or the department. One particular business is close to my electorate. In fact, one of the people involved lives in my electorate. Small Australian investors put up collectively $350,000 to get' this business running. This person was going to employ Australians to provide beer at a cheap price that was manufactured on their premises. In the process of setting up that business, they decided to do the right thing and talk to the Australian Customs Service. This afternoon I received a copy of the letter that they will got back from the Australian Customs Service, which states: In response to your fax and our earlier telephone conversation, I am able to advise that the Beer Brewing Hobby shop you intend to establish will not require licensing from the Australian Customs Service. Premises need to be licensed under the Excise Act when they are used to manufacture an excisable product. Beer produced for non-commercial purposes is not excisable under the Excise Tariff Act. I point out again that the $350,000 was invested by the people in this venture. I find this process fascinating in that approximately a week after the budget was brought downnot before-when these people were concerned about the quote that I made earlier about the budget, the minister's staff asked those in this industry to send him information on what they do and details of the Canadian industry. Where did he find out about the Canadian industry? Secondly, why, one week after the budget was brought down, was the minister seeking information to this effect? It gets even worse. On Friday of last week, the minister's staff visited the business in Melbourne to talk about what they did. This is the that industry that the government decided in the budget to introduce an excise on. The people who run this business were advised by the minister's staff that the matter would be taken to a caucus committee, probably on Monday of this week, and discussed. Why did Customs not believe that the business required licensing? I have read the quote; I have the letter. It clearly made that comment when these people went to look at establishing the business. If the minister had to send his staff down in the last week to find out what this business did in detail, why at page 4.16 of the budget do we have a section that talks about applying an excise to this particular industry? We are. talking about a very new, small industry in this country. We are talking about an industry that has four shops, not hundreds. There is one in Perth, Melbourne, Sydney and Newcastle. What do those shops do? I will try, for the record, to get some of the details out in the open. A' brew on premises operation provides a service where conSumers can brew and bottle beer for their own consumption. Customers choose the particular recipe that suits them; they purchase the ingredients; they rent the equipment on site; and control their own brew from the start to the finish. The question arises: do they actually manufacture beer? Beer is brewed on the premises but the customer physically makes his own beer from start to finish. According to the budget statement, beer brewed at home for personal consumption will remain exempt from excise duty. Beer brewed by amateurs at a brew on premises shop, which is made by customers and is for their· own personal consumption, will not be exempt. The excise on this particular industry will cause dramatic problems for the people who have established these businesses-in many instances investing their life savings to do so-and will also affect the customers by making the beer they like more expensive. It is important to look at the growth that was expected in this industry over the next six years. In 1993 there were four shops producing 460,800 Htres of beer. In 1994 that was expected to expand. to seven shops; in 1995, to 14; in 1996, to 43; and in 1997, to 115. In 1998---:one would expect anY industry trying to get itself up and operating to make these sorts of projections-there was exPected to be 150 operations establis1:led throughout Australia. On the basis of 150 shops being established over a period of six years, the brew on. premises operation .expected to generate approximately $187 million in turnover-a not insignificant amount. It also expected to establish 750 jobs for Australians in Australia. One obvious question is whether this type of operation would cause problems for the commercial brewing industry.. I suspect that has been an area of concern for some people. The answer is that it will have little effect the commercial industry. According to Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, the total commercial production for 1991-92 was 1,862,304,000 litres. Assuming no growth or even decline over the next six years, that equates to 11, 173,OOO,000-plus liires of beer. The total brew on premises production estimated over that six years is 36 million litres. That represents between half and one per cent of the estimated commercial productioq.. It should be noted that this percentage assumes that all brew on premises production will displace commercial production. Realistically, 30 per cent of the brew on premises production will come from current home brewers, 20 per cent from imported beer drinkers, 10 per cent from new beer drinkers, and only 40 per cent of customers will be attracted from commercial operations. So only about a quarter of one per cent or less than a quarter of one per cent-0.14 per cent - of the (;ommercial brewing industry turnover would be affected by the expansion of this new industry.. We should take note of the revenue expected to be generated by this taxation measure. From the figures provided by the brew on premises people, it is estimated that over the next six years there will be $187,913,100 in turnover. It is estimated that the excise on that amount would be in the order of $8,530,699. We .need to be clear about the· effect that would have on the industry. It would virtually prevent it from getting off the ground. It is estimated that the direct tax revenue from this operation through ,employee income tax contributions and wholesale sales taxwholesale sales tax will still be paid as part of this operation-will be $11,409,084. Without the imposition of the proposed excise, this industry would develop and create 750 jobs and the country would gain tax revenue in excess of $11 million. But what have we done? In effect, we have said to this industry, on very questionable grounds, that we really do not want it around. Some people might query that comment. I direct them to page 4.6 and table 3 of the budget papers where the income expected to on be generated as a result of this measure is set out. For 1993-94, the revenue expected to be achieved from micro-brewers is zero; for 1994-95, revenue expected to be received, zero; for 1995-96, revem.·- expected to be achieved by these taxes, zero; for 1996-97, revenue expected to be achieved by this government, zero. In fact, according to the budget papers, for every year that this particular item appears, zero tax is expected to be collected. , . , Anyone reading the Treasurer's budget statement would think that he was trying, to create jobs aQd opportunities for Australians to get work. I remi,nd the Treasurer that this particular industry does not require especially skilled people. lIere is an opportunity Jor us to give jobs to average Australians who might not have the qualities to enable them to become engineers or engage in some other very skilled occupation. Even after one of its own departments advised this industry that it would not be hit with taxes, the government has chosen to make this entry in the budget papers. Yet, at the end of the day, when the revenue to be raised is calculated, the government can expect to get absolutely zero. I want to say something now about an industry where problems will arise because of increaseS in the fuel excise. There is a petrol station in my electorate which takes about 10 tanker loads of fuel a month. If we average out the 5c excise increase on unleaded petrol and the 8c increase on leaded petrol excise at 7c a litre, because there are more cars using leaded fuel than not at the moment, then over the next two years that service station is looking at a tax hike per tanker load of 40,000 litres multiplied by 7c, which is $2,800. With 10 tankers a month, that is $28,000 of additional tax. Petrol stations pay cash for their petrol. What we should remember is that 50 per cent of. station customers are account customers with 30-day accounts. There is 30 days in which they can buy fuel, and 30 days before they have to pay for it. That means that $28,000 in additional cash flow has to be found by that business. In fact, most people do not even pay on a 30-day account basis; it is more like 60 days in the climate of this recession that we had to have. That means that this particular business could be up for a $42,000 cash outlay in order to keep going. I am talking about small Australian businesses. We must remember that they are operated by Australian people. I aSk the government to think about giving sales tax,benefits to seas businesses, such as Cathay Pacific(Tzme expired)  p.m.)-I rise to speak on Appropriation Bill (No.1) 1993-94. In the current world climate, any Treasurer bringing down a budget is going to have a difficult time. If we look at the Western economies of the world, we see the blight of the world as being unemployment. However, despite our difficulties, everybody recognises that we are doing better than all other Western economies. The budget predicts a growth rate of one per cent in jobs-not fast enough to pull down in appreciable terms the pool of unemployment, but still better than other Western economies are doing. We have a predicted growth rate of 2.75 per cent in the size of the economy-again, not as fast as we need, not as fast as we would want to see, but faster than any other Western economy in the world. Everybody in this chamber recognises that there are not any magic solutions; there are not any magic wands to wave that are suddenly going to repair the 'Oifficulties that are faced by all Western economies. But, if we are going to increase the level of growth in this economy, and if we are going to increase the opportunity for employment, then we have to help our businesses to grow; help them to expand; help them to make a' greater contribution to replacing imports; and help with the identification and generation of new businesses. That is the only way that we are going to create the jobs that we need. So we need to identify and grasp new opportunities. I am going to refer to' some matters that go to that objective. At the same time as we face the difficulty of falling commodity prices for our major exports, we do have the offset of the corresponding fall in the value of the dollar. That helps with our exports and with import replacement, in that it makes domestically produced products more attractive. I would like to dwell on the positive side of the budget, as contrasted with the negative side as put by those opposite. The budget provisions create a - etter climate for growth. The bringing forward of the taxation cuts of over- $2 billion to mid-November-previously scheduled for 1 July next year-will provide . a decided impetus to the budget. In 1983 the company tax rate was 49c in the dollar. Under this budget we have a further cut from 39c in the dollar to 33c in the dollar. The new company tax rate, the general investment allowances to boost investment in plant, the extension of the developmental allowance, and the earlier accelerated depreciation allowances in previous budgets are all components that help to generate greater investment in business, and generate the growth that we need. Some years ago this government abolished double taxation of dividends and that has been of enormous assistance to incorporated businesses. That initiative has not been recognised, and has perhaps been studiously avoided by those opposite and by .those who benefit. That measure alone cost some $300 million in the first year. The purpose of that measure was to encourage Australians to invest in Australian business, to encourage Australian business to incorporate, and to overcome the heavy burden of tax on company profits which were further taxed, by way of personal income tax, when they were distributed to shareholders. To that climate we must add the considerable improvement in labour productivity over the years, the considerable reduction in real labour costs and the fact that we are now experiencing the lowest interest rates for 20 years and the lowest inflation rates for 30 years. The result is a climate shaped to generate investment in corporate Australia, and to help businesses grow and seek out new opportunities. Let me identify some of the packages and operations that have been devised to stimulate business. We have a $94 million package to give local firms better access to export opportunities. I refer here to the market Australia campaign, the range of improved export programs and the first-stop shops. Under the market Australia campaign some $21 million has been provided over the next three years to promote Australia externally as a high quality manufacturer. We have shaken off the old idea in this country that 'if it is imported, it is better'. We have to convince markets abroad that, if it is made in Australia, it is good, it is reliable and it is quality; The market Australia campaign over the next three years will help create an image of Australian products . b-ing quality products, of being consistently reliable, and of prices being much more competitive. I tum next to the international trade enhancement .scheme. That scheme provides financial support for the expansion and acceleration of export marketing activities to help potential exporters. Over the next two years we are going to provide a further $26 million to some 15 to 20 identified medium to small exporters who do not have access to the present scheme because they cannot demonstrate the likelihood of generating a $20 million sale in foreign exchange over the next five years. This extra $26 million will help identify those 15 to 20 firms that do not presently benefit. It is expected that some $500 miIJion in export income will be generated over the five life years of each project. I move on to the establishment of the online computer service called Business Link. One of the major problems of small to medium businesses in Australia is that they do not know what help is available, from what government, for what purpose, or who to contact to get that help. Business Link will go some way towards providing that information about government programs, about government services and even about potential export markets. The government is providing $7.9 million for that purpose over three years. I want to move to a very important service, the National Industry Extension ServiceNIBS. Under NIES there is going to be an extra $12 million of funding available over the next three years. That funding will enable smaller firms to get greater assistance to improve their market opportunities both locally and overseas, to enable them to adopt best practice and to enable them to meet export requirements. It is clear that industry associations are going to have to play an important part in that objective. Linked to that will be an extension of export-access. Export access is a trade facilitation and enterprise development program for small and medium exporters, and it will receive an extra $8 million over the next three years. That extra $8 million will enable a further 800 companies to develop export potential. We find over and over again that small to medium businesses in Australia have a product, they know they can make it, but they do not have access to, or do not know how to go about searching out, a market even in other parts of regional Australia. Those businesses do not know how to go about getting government assistance for product improvement. They do not know who to see. We often find in the Hunter and the Central Coast that there are firms that have by-law exemption from customs duty, but because they do not have access to advice they are paying the duty. They do not know what they ought to be doing. I can go to· no better authority than Bert Evans, the chief executive of the Metal Trades Industry Associatiori, the most effective arid forward looking of the industry associations in Australia. Bert Evans spoke at the Queensland branch annual dinner recently, and he said: Governments can provide the operating infrastructure for manufacturers, but only company managements and their wodd'orces can deliver the goods. You and I know that managements and people on the shopfloor do not spontaneously move oneas to adopt new Goverriment incentives. They do not automatically seize the opportunities provided by government policies which give access to a better financial or marketing environment. The reason is, that they need leadership. He went on to say: "The key issue, both for individual firms and for the nation overall, is that of leadership-having .vision and commitment to tum . . . opportunities into reality". In that last paragraph he is quoting from the MCKinsey and Co. report that was released earlier this year. But Me Evans makes the very valid point that those of us who move around industry know only too well: no matter how good the product is, no matter how good the marketing may be and no inatter how good or enthusiastic people working on the shop floor may be, leadership and enthusiasm have to come from top management. If we have stultified top or middle management, this country will not get the benefit it is entitled to get from the available programs and from those companies that could be doing more for Australia but are not doing more because that leadership - is not there. I want to tum briefly to what is happening in our regions. I am talking here of extending some of those programs I have referred to and of the effect they c.an have in regions like the Hunter, the Central Coast and other parts of regional Australia. Contrary to the view put in the Industry Commission report released a few days ago, regional Australia has a major impediment to growth and opportunity. That major impediment is the fact that corporate Australia does not see beyond the boardrooms of the capital cities. For so many corporations, the world begins and ends in Melbourne and Sydney. They do not recognise the Hunter. They do not recognise the Central Coast. They do not think about the: Latrobe Valley. They do not think about all oUhe other regions that exist in this country where there is a stable work force, good training facilities, lower commercial rents, lower housing costs, a more attractive . environment and where there are people of talent and skill who are very committed to making theiJ: work a success and helping to make company operations a success. The major impediment to growth in those regions is not the fault of government in most cases. It is almost always the failure of Australian corporations to look beyond the environments of the capital cities. So in those programs we need to see the corporations the looking to take up the opportunities and utilise and build upon the benefits in the regions of Australia. In the case of the regional tourism development referred to in the budget, an amount of $5.5 million is allocated under Tourism Australia. That program is designed to help with the development of regional tourism by improving and helping the capacity of regional areas to attract both international and domestic tourists. Those grants will help in the area of integrated regional planning and in the provision of tourism infrastructure. Under the same Tourism Australia heading there is the provision of $2.7 million to provide funding for the cooperative marketing of backpacker accommodation, assistance in the development of farm based tourism, the development of a cruise shipping strategy to encourage greater use of Australia as a cruise destination and a base port for cruise ships, and the international promotion of Australia as a cruise shipping destination. We want to see the cooperative marketing of backpacker accommodation. Again, the regions of Australia have so much to offer to backpacker tourists coming to this country. For example, there are the low accommodation costs, there is so much to see and there is the advantage of being able to move around more cheaply. They can see a part of Australia ,they will not see walking the main streets of the capital cities. In respect of cruise ship operations, a port such as Newcastle lends itself ideally to the development of cruise operations based out of that port, bringing people in and taking people out. But all of the cruise ship operations essentially are centred on Sydney, with some on the north Barrier Reef. Using ports other than those I have referred to provides an opportunity to open up the regional hinterlands to tourists. Cruise shipping and that $2.7 million allocated under Tourism Australia can provide opportunities for benefits to be developed in the Hunter and the Central Coast whose economies are intertwined. I tum now to something else in respect of the people side of the budget. One of the great problems of people who are unemployed is that when they get the opportunity for short-term work they face the sheer hassle of taking that work. Getting a resumption of their jobsearch or newstart allowance is difficult, there is bureaucratic involvement and errors can take place. When people are living hard and trying to get by on support during periods of unemployment, their family budget cannot withstand the kinds of interruptions that can happen when they take shortterm work. When that short-term employment is difficult to take up and the income interrupnance, tion is more than the family can stand, it is often so easy just to not get involved. If they do not get involved and they do not grasp the opportunity then they also miss out on the opportunity of what could be continuing employment. So from 20 March 1994, the unused income test free area can be accumulated. In other words, up to $500 will be able to be accumulated to be offset as an additional free area against future income from employment by jobsearch allowance, newstart allowance and sickness allowance recipients. That $10.5 million provided in the budget will help those people to grab the chance of getting some short-term work and staying on in the work force, even if it is only for a short time. It will give them the chance to keep touch with the work force and maintain and utilise some of their skills. We expect that some 26,000 people will benefit from that provision in the budget. Similarly, in the case of the long-term unemployed and mature age unemployed, we are addressing the problem of people over the age of 60 who have been registered as unemployed for more than 12 months and who have been in receipt of income support for more than 12 months. We are providing them with the opportunity to take up a mature age allowance-to transfer to a more generous allowance than they are already receiving under newstart, with no activity test requirements. It is estimated that 26,000 people will benefit from the introduction of the mature age allowance. That, again, is a recognition of the problems of the people in that age group and the difficulties of the long-term unemployed in gaining employment. In that higher age group we also have the seniors health card. There is the provision of $800,000 in the budget for the introduction of the seniors health card from 1 July 1994 for people of pension age and veterans of service pension age whose incomes, as assessed under the pension income test, are below the pension cut-out point. That card will provide access for those people to concessional pharmaceuticals, free hearing aids and concessional services for hearing aid mainteand access to ,the Commonwealth dental program for health card holders. The first stage of the emergency dental scheme will commence on 1 January 1994, and then there will be a broader dental health care service on 1 July 1994. Optometry services will also become available for those people under Medicare. Again, we are looking to those people in the community who have found things difficult, particularly when employment opportunities are harder to come by. A budget measure also addresses instances where people are receiving incomes that are below· the pension cut-out point. Through those last few measures I have referred to, I am trying to show that the government, through the budget, is moving to try to stimulate business, create greater business growth, create opportunities for business to get under way. and expand markets, and create opportunities for new businesses to form and to identify new opportunities to generate the jobs that will be the only solution to the problems that the Western world is facing. Following on from that is how we assist those who are unemployed-those who have been able to get some short-term work and those mature age people who have not been able to get work for over 12 months or who have been in receipt of income support for over 12 months. For years and years, I know that honourable members on both sides of this chamber have had representations from people for the provision of dental health care. The provision of $19.2 million in this budget goes to the introduction of emergency dental care and basic dental services. Under this arrangement, funds will be provided to the states to enable the expansion of service capacity within their existing dental programs covering health care card holders. There is provision in. that arrangement for private dentists to participate, but that is something that the states will have to decide themselves. The emergency dental scheme will be introduced on 1 January 1994 and the broader dental scheme that I referred to for the seniors card holders will be available to all health card holders from 1 July. The general dental scheme will cover examinations, simple preventative treatments and restorative treatments. The last matter I want to mention is the extension of child-care assistance and the provision of the home child-care allowance. Both those measures recognise the problems that families have, whether two-income families or where one spouse has gone out to work, wife or husband. Those measures are long overdue and have been demanded by the community. They represent a considerable investment by government to help Australian families. Contrary to the doom and gloom that comes from some people with respect to the budget, I have tried in these few short minutes to outline the benefits both to business and to Australian families.

Speaker: Mr DOBIE
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I listened to the honourable  speak glowingly of the Hunter. Strangely, I support him in all he said, except when he talked about buying Australian goods. Margaret Thatcher, who was the Prime Minister of Britain-as you, Mr Deputy Speaker, may remember-said that she did not want the British to buy British because it was British but because it was the best. So I believe it should be for Australians, buying Australian, not because it is Australian, but because it is the best. Apart from that, I agree with everything the honourable member for Shortland had to say..

Speaker: Mr DOBIE
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: I thank the honourable member. Painted on the side of a building on one of Sydney's busiest streets is a comment which caught my attention last week. It read, 'Call a federal election nOW-Australia is going bankrupt'. I cannot be sure exactly how long that message has greeted drivers along that street. Perhaps it was there before the budget. However, I rather suspect it was a response to the Dawkins budget. It is a response which is representative of the complete rejection by the Australian community of the Dawkins budget. It is a response symbolic of the community outrage at the Keating Labor government and the path down which it is leading the country. Mr Deputy Speaker, since I was first elected to this parliament in 1966, I cannot recall a budget which has been so swiftly and comprehensively damned by all sections of the community as this second Dawkins budget. What is even more remarkable is the degree of outrage which came from traditional Labor supporters-in particular the ACTU. Who will ever forget the bucket Martin Ferguson tipped on the government when the budget was only hours old? The Labor Party is in disarray. I know that the Special Minister of State (Me Walker), who is at the table, agrees with me. the plot to such an extent that the old guard has abandoned it. It cannot rely even on its staunchest supporters to advocate this budget. Even they cannot 'defend the indefensible', as Martin Ferguson put it. Whether they are church groups, social service organisations, students, pensioners, health workers, economists-a good group-family groups, retirees and trade unionists, the bottom line is that they have all branded this budget a complete failure, both for Australia and for the individual concerns they represent. Mr Deputy Speaker, I cannot recall a budget which has died so swift a death as this one. In only the second week of the budget session, the government was forced to back down on its ill-considered proposals. Now, in the fourth week-can it be only that long?we are faced with the unprecedented introduction of further budget bills because this government just cannot get its act together. Never have I seen a budget so roundly condemned. As I have done the rounds of my ekctorate, I have never heard so much anger from ordinary people as I have in response to the Dawkins budget. Mr Deputy Speaker, the parliament now has before it a budget which contains the most horrendous measures for ordinary Australian families. They must be opposed. These measures must be opposed because the government has no mandate to introduce them. More importantly, they must be opposed out of dignity for the ordinary Australian family, the family that Labor has forgotten, the family which is to be burdened with extra taxes and payments and reduced services, the family that has felt the full brunt of the worse sion in 60 years and the family that has been deliberately misled by a government which, at the last election, desperate to hold on to office, made outrageous promises which it knew it could not keep. These are the people that Labor has abandoned in this budget and it is for the welfare of these families that the coalition made the decision to oppose the tax increases. It is also for the welfare of small business proprietors, pensioners, independent retirees and young people that the coalition will oppose the It has lost Keating-Dawkins tax slugs. Mr Deputy Speaker, I anticipate that my electorate office is akin to many around the country. My office has been deluged with calls and letters from angry, frustrated constituents who understandably are irate at the government's budget measures. As t have said, the response has been unprecedented. So it is for the constituents of Cook that I stand in protest at this budget tonight. Mr Deputy Speaker, the government's so called deficit reduction strategy is fundamentally flawed-just plain bad economics. With this budget the government has not confronted the big issues. It has merely skirted around the fringe. This is evidenced by the forward estimates which show that there will be no reduction in unemployment and no sustainable growth over the coming year. We can witness the silence of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley)- These estimates confirm the defeatist nature of· the budget and send alarming signals to potential investors in this country. The recent volatility of the dollar is testament-to that. Mr Deputy Speaker, in this budget tp.e government had an opportunity to introduce measqres to reduce unemployment. In the words of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins): The greatest issue facing our nation is how to provide jobs for our fellow Australians. But the reality is that this budget does nothing to get Australia back to work. It is forecast that in 12 months time the level of unemployment will be 10.75 per cent. The rate at the time of the budget-seasonally adjusted-was 10.7 per cent. What does that tell us about the recesKeating Labor. government's motivation to reduce unemployment? Quite clearly, Labor has given up on the unemployed. Despite some nonsense spoken in this House two weeks ago by government members, they have no commitment to get the unemployed people of Australia back to work. The Labor approach is simply to hike up a few more taxes and run up a huge deficit to pay the benefits. It is not interested in getting the economy growing at a sufficient rate to create jobs. The Labor Party's interest lies in ways of finding the money to pay the huge welfare bill for the people it has put on social security. We can see this in the budget papers, where the appropriations for unemployment payments for the coming year are detailed. Appropriations for newstart al10wance payments have increased while the overal1 appropriation for jobsearch payments has fal1en. It is clear from these figures that the government is expecting long-term unemployment to increase over the coming year. That is cold comfort for the nearly one mi11ion people out of work in this country-and who wi11 remain unemployed. The response from the Brotherhood of St Laurence to the budget is representative of the government's approach to the problem of unemployment. It said: The government has missed a chance to act sively on unemployment and people on low comes will continue to suffer. That is the hal1mark of this budget. It compounds our existing problems and offers no hope for recovery, in particular to pressing economic problem of unemployment. But this budget does worse than that: it slugs the unemployed and low income earners with tax increases. In return for the increase taxes, the government plans to give low income earners a pathetic $100 rebate for year-less than $2 a week. This was wel1 covered by my leader in his superb response to the budget. This is the alleged compassionate and sharing Labor government.· This is the governgovernment ment which 'will not let down' the battlers Australia. It did not take the government to show its true colours-the shame and deceit. It is worth remembering how those groups which represent the poorest people in the community view the budget. The Australian Council of Social Service said that it was 'deeply disappointing and will hurt low income people'. The Council on the Ageing said the budget was 'marked by a meanness and emphasises the lack of care for pensioners and low income older people'. The Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission said it was regressive, while the St Vincent de Paul Society is genuinely concerned about the government's commitment for people to break out of the welfare cycle, and so one could go on and on. It is very clear that those organisations representing the low income and disadvantaged families have branded this budget as an abject failure, and so it is. But that should not be a surprise to members of this House. Certainly, on my side, we are never surprised at the depth the Labor Party will descend to in government. Even members of the government now brace themselves for a backlash on those rare occasions that they get out amongst their electorates and try to explain the latest decision. Just to give you an idea, Mr Deputy Speaker, the phones in my electorate office have been constantly ringing. The most common question I am asked is, 'How we can get rid deciof the Keating government?'. Even those inpeople who. did not vote for me are now asking my advice to see whether there is anything in the constitution which can be used to throw out the government. That is the the most extent of the community outrage. There are some items in the budget which I feel' I must address. The first is in relation to the decision to scrap the Medicare benefit in for optometrical procedures. The government is to be condemned for this outrageous decia sion. Let us not forget that in one hit the Labor government caused untold community anxiety and jeopardised the jobs of many people employed in the field of optometry. This is a shameful and despicable act from a which accused the opposition at of the last election of wanting to dismantle long Medicare when in fact that was not part of colours of our campaign at al1. The Labor Party has increased the Medicare payment to 1.4 per cent and almost simultaneously tried to take away the rebate for optometry. There is no justification for this, and the public should remember why the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) wanted to do that. I 'congratulate the eye care industry for the strength and intelligence of its opposition to this proposal. Thankfully, after considerable pressure had been exerted by the coalition, the optometrical profession and the Australian community, it now appears that the government has abandoned this ill-conceived measure. But the terms of the Keating turnaround have to be watched very closely, and I give my word that I shall be watching for any other sneaky moves by the crew of the Treasurer. But the fact remains that the Labor government-in particular the officers of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer-had thought it was good policy to strip ordinary Australian families of their Medicareentitlemerit to optometry visits. Rest assured that this backdown from the government is not part of some' process. of listening to the concerns of the electorate; it is the concession it has had to make to get itS budget legislation passed. Let· there be no mistake---the government has not had a change of heart. The Labor Party thinks it is a good idea to make struggling families pay mo-e for their children to have their eyes checked. It is only the government's lack of a majority in the Senate which stopped it. Let all Australians remember. Similarly, the Labor Party thinks it is a good idea to, hike up the tax on petrol but reduce spending on roads. It believes there is no inequity in forcing those families which are least able to afford it to pay more for their petrol. Only the government's lack of a majority in the Senate stopped it from increasing it all the way. Mr Deputy Speaker, this Keating government thinks that to retrospectively. tax someone's accumulated long service leave to increase a person's tax liability by some thousands of dollars overnight-is a good idea. It thinks that to deceive people in such a fraudulent manner is good government and, again, only a lack of a majority in the Senate stopped it. These are the measures which the Australian people will not forget, and be warned, they will not forget, and nor should they.
