One can only imagine what nasties the Labor Party would have inflicted on the Australian community had it had a majority in the Senate .. Thankfully for the welfare of this country, .it does not. I want to make that point patently clear. This is a major embarrassing backdown for the government, and it deserves to be condemned for the way it has been railroaded into caving in on its budget announcements. It is due only to the coalition's steadfast refusal to allow the Australian public to be slugged with unfair and discriminatory tax hikes that the government was forced to compromise with the Democrats and the Greens. This is no, change of heart. Believe me, there is no change of heart. This is a government which cannot get the support of the parliament, the community, its mates in the union movement or even its own backbench for its first budget of the 37th parliament. Let us not have the community fooled. Labor wanted to tax people more. Labor wanted to make people pay more for eye vi-its, and Labor wanted to rob people's accumulated long service leave entitlement. We would not let it get away with. that. The last sitting fortnight was truly a remarkable session in politics. The government could not get the budget passed intact; it could not organise the legislative timetable; its union supporters bucketed the budget in Sydney; and the backbench revolted against the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. We know that the backbench had no knowledge and input into the budget. Even the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) did not know that the sales tax on wine was to be increased in the budget. What a complete and utter shambles this government has got itself into and, as the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) said, it only has itself to blame. In the moments left to me, I want to address the appalling performance of the Prime Minister in the wake of the budget. His attempts to blame everybody except himself and his government for the recent fall in the dollar is qothing short of being politically contemptible. It truly is a remarkable situation when we have the leader of this country stooping to such a despicable degradation of the office of Prime Minster. He has proved quite conclusively that the post of Prime Minister is clearly beyond his capabilities, arid his attempts to blame all artd sundry around him for his own incompetence are clearly transparent and have not been taken seriou-ly by the average Australian. This budget which we are debating tonight is a dud. That is why there is uncertainty in financial markets. That is why the Reserve Bank has had to step into try to prop up the dollar. That is why the unions, the Labor party backbench and all community organisations are protesting. That is' why ordinary Australians hold the Prime Minister and his government in such low esteem, as recent polls have confirmed. The Prime Minister has no-one to: blame but himself. As someone who once boasted that he is in control of all the levers, his attempts to put the ..blame on everybody but himself is all the more remarkable. Some years ago-1977, in facf-I drew the attention of the House to comments made by the United States Secretary of the Treasury, the honourable William Simon, when he addressed a meeting of the World Bank in Manila.' He said: Unfortunately, good economics is not always perceived to be good politics. My experierice has been that politics is an art with a high rate of discount. And while the pay-off to good economics is real, it tak!!S time. This lag, as the economists call it, is a p6litician's nightmare. Fortunately, I think that more and more people now understand that this is the case-and I sense gro\ving suspicion of the proposed instant solution, the quick fix. IIi a world of unlimited demands and limited resources, finance ministers are not only inevitably unpopular but indeed cannot afford to be popular. We are required to be the bearers of bad tidings-to reiterate the unpleasant but inescapable fact that resources are scarce while wants are limitless. It is our lot, whatever our country's economic system and whatever its circumstances, to speak out for financial responsibility-to call for prudence an age of fiscal adventure. Mr Deputy Speaker, in that same speech, I made mention of Micawber's simple statement. Micawber, as honourable members will recall, is a character from David Copperfield. Micawber in tum migrated to Australia. He said: Annual income £20 Os. Od.; annual expenditure £19 19s. 6d.; result happiness. Annual income £20 Os. Od.; annual expenditure £20 Os. 6d.; result misery. . Th- Special Minister of State would be a-are of that. I think those words are still apt today, qnly we could perhaps 'lll'date the figur-s, where the difference is not 6d but $16 billion. So be it! I have never resorted to personal abuse in this House, and I do nqt intenq to do so today but, by gosh, i have been sorely tempted to do so. ... I want to finish by saying that the Olympic games are a tremendous boost. Let us not forget that federally we have done nothing. 1n fact, the strong word doing the rounds is that the Ministyr for the Environment, SpoI:t and Territories (Mrs Kelly) was powerless. She did not try to convince the Treasurer to rally support behind Sydney's successful application for the games. All we hear about is, 'Change the flag' and 'Change the constitution'. The answer by' all Australians to this Labor government's budget is, 'Shame, shame, shame'.

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: I must make some comments on the closing rem-rks of my friend the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie). !felt they were out of character for his normal demeanour in this place and quite unbecoming of him. I will go slightly'further and suggest that, whilst the nation has celebrated the winning bf the Olympics for Sydney for the year 2000, we have to ensure that the management of the major expenditure on the games is done very carefully from a public point of view. . We have had some bad experience in this country of major government projects, particularly in New South Wales; and I am confident that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) will be ensuring that the system of management used in by New South Wales is transparent and open and that it stays bipartisan. That is absolutely vital. The games were won because the nation was united-state, federal and local government on both sides of politics-and they will be successful only if that bipartisanship is maintained throughout the management instantaneously, process. The budget is an extremely complex ,docusector ment. We can talk glibly about over $110 billion worth of expenditure. If we look at volumes that are involved and the sheer details of it, the tendency is to ove-implify it. For the consumption of the public at large it needs to be simplified, bIlt unfortunately are seeing it being trivialised. I think the comments from so many honourable members opposite,have basically been to ,denigrate just the budget but the country and ,the econanalysis omy itself. We understand that there has been a 'great deal of uncertainty about the world's future. For example, in August, of last year Japanese government decided to spend money to try to stimulate the, economy. ' It 'did that again in April of this year and again a few weeks ago- In other words, three times in just over 12 months the Japanese government has taken measures to try to improve its recov-ry. I think President Bush lost his presidency because the American forecasters misforecast the American econo-y. Thi!;l also happened in Germany and Britain. Those countries have been in a state of confusion,and in,dilficulties with their economies-there has been a lack of growth, as projected-which have had an effect on their currencies. It is, therefore, of interest to look at has happened' in Australia' over the last three or foUr budgets in ternis of forecastirig.For all but one of the last five budgets the Treasury forecasts were much closer' to the actual outcome than the, average, of the private forecasts. Yet in some cases they were still grievously wrong, as were t-e treasury foreopposition casts, as I said, in Germany, Japan, Britain, France and the United StateS of America. We have .seen world ,econ()mies changing so dramatically and so rapidly and in a way that has meant the forecasting and accumulation of data, the synthesis and projection, almost had no relationship at times to what actually occurs. Fundamentally, forecasting is based on previous experience. Whether it is because of electronics, because of a capacity to move money around globally much more quiekly transactions, instantaneously or virtually and because'of the centralisation of the international economy where one is progressing well in a particular country and another sector adjacent to it is the performing badly-there are probably many more reasons-I do not think there is much doubt that the capacity of the world's treasuries to adequately analyse and forecast anywe thing more thaw weeks or months ahead at a time is very poor. ,It is therefore of some substance and some importance that we as a ,not country undertake a much more detailed of unemployinent and its impIlcations than perhaps we have in the past. Perhaps we have assumed that understanding history was enough. We have not underthe stood that the language of history has changed. The technology of history is different, and if we are to understand the future we certainly have to change the method by which we interpret the past. The fact is that the methods are not available. We cannot go back five, 10 and 15 years and analyse the movements in sectors of the economy that we now need to do for the future. Anybody who attempts'to project the economy from 10, 15 or 20 years ago in any substantial way into the future will very likely find that it will not perform in the same way. Communities are affected by these things. We have the economists forecasting and the politicians prophesying. Certainly the prophets of doom opposite what have been having something of a field day. Eventually the community at large reacts in 'much simpler terms to what it sees, as I indicated earlier, as trivialisation. This trivialising anddoomsaying becomes self-fulfilling. If we keep telling our community, as the has done so constantly for so long, that things are bad, things will become bad. Eventually the effect of people's cautiousness and uncertainty is for the economy to contract. The more the economy contracts, the more difficult it is for the economy to recover. " wlien we have eminent citizens-I consider the previous speaker, the honourable member for Cook, to be one-making such gloomy forecasts and prognoses and, more than that, in putting motivation to them, we have more than trivialisation; we have a distortion of fairly substantial magnitude. All parliamentarians read the budget; they all look at the details. There is not a parliamentarian in this· House who is not aware of the complexity of the document or the forecasts or of what is happening in the rest of the world's economies. The sheer dishonesty of what has been going on in the last four or five weeks is mind-boggling. It is not enough to say that it is simply politics. It is not politics. It is about the future of the country. The fundamental problem we have' iti the country is unemployment and its impacts on people. This budget, and the' appropriation bills that accompany it, substantially address the questions of unemployment, training and work generation. In the absence of consumer confidence-and that is not surprising, given what the consumers are being told-it is fundamental . that. the government in fact spends. This budget is an investment back into the economy. The budget puts· more money back than it takes. We heard that referred to earlier by the previous speaker in a negative sense. The opposition's proposals earlier this year were for the government to extract money from the economy to actually reduce the deficit, to withdraw.the money in . circulation. The natural impact of that is contraction and, hence, further. recession. This budget is stimulatory. The government is attempting to be countercyclical, injecting money into the economy to stimulate demand, as are the governments in Japan, Germany, Britain, France and virtually every other Western economy. .This budget does much more than that because it targets quite specifically areas of labour and employment. The major areas 9f growth are vocational and industry training, which is at 6 1/2 per cent of real growth; labour market assistance to, job seekers, grewing at 71f2 per cent; and employment services, growing at 10.7 per cent. These are all fundamental signals to our community that growth will come with that sort of investment. In. the process, - t also generates a higher level of skill. . If we look in more detail at vocational and industry training, we see growth in the budget overall from last year of nine per cent, particularly for entry level training and skills. training in areas such as group training for. companies, the trainet;Ship system, special trad- training and the ABC and career start apprentic-hips. All have been substantially increased in this budget and are aimed at imprqving the' skills because' eventually this country has ,to be about skill. So it· is not simply a question of investing in supporting people who are out of work; it is ensuring that, as work emerges and as the economy recovers, the work force and those who are seeking to become members of the work force are capable of winning work. It is not simply unemployment that we must be concerned about; .. we must be particularly concerned about long-term unemployment. . . I want. to quote some figures from the Newcastle area in terms of the impact of these programs and what they are doing to assist the long-term unemployed. In programs like jobtrain and jobstart,.· the percentages of commencements of the long-term unemployed in July and August were 62 per cent and 57 per cent· respeCtively. In other words, the programs' were predominantly being used to assist those who ha:dbeen out of work for more than 12 months. That is a fundamentally important factor. . The positive outcomes-long-term unemployeq people who a,re in employment or full time training thr- mon.ms after completion of their placem-nt-show. that 38 percent of those people are either in work or in training. . The overall job placement by CES-in other words, all of the jqbs found in those months fo- the long-term unemployed-was 34 per cent. That is sayi,ng that the programs themselves are effective in the sense that people who are the least !lble to compete, those who have been out of work the longest, are in fact now competing quite successfully." ',. . " , -,' Hence, the expenditure in those particular training areas, in the labour market assistance areas, is so vital. This is why it is so. important to note that.in this particular budget the increase in the labour market system to job seekers and to. industry has increased by just over 10 per cent to a figure of $1.36 billion. I That $1.36: billion is a subst;mtial investment in labour market assistance, and that is just one part. For the record I want to list some of those areas because I think it is important for people to understand the cohesion that this program involves. Programs incorporated into that expenditure include jobstart, which facilitates employment by providing temporary partial wage subsidies to employers-in other words, we are assisting employers to take on a person. Jobtrain provides short-tenn vocational training linked to individual needs and local labour markets. The new enterprise incentive scheme, NElS, provides training and income support to assist unemployed people to set up small business ventures. Skillshare provides grants to non-profit community organisations for structured skills training, and, of course, in Newcastle we have some superb skillshares; it is extremely effective and successful. Jobskills provides dised work experience in local government and the community sector for long-tenn unemployed people. We have jobclubs which have almost doubled in this year's budget from $13.3 million to $25.5 million. Jobclubs provide intensive training courses on job seeking skills. The accredited training program for youth, ATY, provides places for youth on accredited training courses, and all of those who achieve that are eligible for jobstart placements. The landcare and environment action program, better known as LEAP, assists young unemployed people to acquire new skills through training and practical experience in landcare. The special intervention program, SIP, provides assessment and remedial training for individuals facing specific employment barriers such as literacy, language or learning difficulties. There is the mobility assistance scheme, the community activity program and the office of labour market adjustment program. I will not go into the details of all of those. I went through some of those programs because people often tend to skip over them very quickly. We assume that the community is aware of all of those programs. The fact is that they present the most comprehensive package of programs ever devised. The figures I quoted earlier about. the successes, particularly in Newcastle-and, I think, nationwide-indicatethat the long-tenn unemployed actually are now starting to compete and to be successful in the job market. It is important. I certainly recall from my experiences in the post-1983 recession from the previous government thl,lt the people who were out of work for a period were finding it extremely difficult to compete. The jobs were going to those who were. either going from jobs or leaving school or training, and the people who were out of work became a group which found. it v:ery difficult to re-enter the work force. With this current. recovery, slow as it may be, the long-term unemployed are getting a fair go; they are actually getting a share of those jobs and will get a better share as those programs move and start to function because fully subsiof the increased expenditure. Those who want to go around bagging the budget and attempting to score political points from it do those unemployed people no justice at all. They have convinced many people that the budget provides no support for them when, in fact, there is quite a substantial amount. I want to move to a problem I mentioned earlier-the forecasting of statistics. I want to reinforce what happens in regional Australia by referring the House to the Bureau of Statistics labour force statistics for New South Wales. In the period September to October last year when the Bureau of Statistics changed the sample, we saw a decrease in the work force in the area of some 20,000 people, virtually within a month. Yet the unemployed did not increase at all; in fact, that statistic went down by 100. Again, in the last few months we have seen a two per cent shift in one month--:unemployment went down by two per cent in one month and up by two per cent a few months later. We have seen these massive changes in regional statistics. I do not wish in any way to diminish the fact that unemployment is high in the regions. There is no question of that. But the figures we are getting are very erratic and very volatile and, more importantly, they are not seasonally adjusted. For example, we cannot compare the Hunter or the lllawarra with Tasmania or South Australia because the Tasmanian figures and the South Australian figures are seasonally adjusted; the regional figures in New South Wales are not. That brings me to the next point. One of the great potentials of this budget for this government is the establishment of the regional development aspects of the industry portfolio. Australia consists of a series of regions, not six states at all. It consists of regionaleconomies which are quite separate and quite different within states and between states. The idea that we can work as a nation by working through our capital cities, as the Bureau of Statistics shows, is just a flawed argument. I and my colleagues from the Hunter have already submitted to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) that, if nothing else, the Bureau of Statistics should start to do its statistics regions on a seasonally adjusted basis and it should also substantially increase the sample size. The statistics we are getting are of no relevance and no benefit to us. They do not allow comparisons on investment or allow people looking at businesses to compare area with area. As I mentioned at the start of my speech, the problems we have had in forecasting fundamentally come back to the instruments we use to forecast. The instruments we used 10 years ago are now inadequate. The instruments we were usmg last year have not successfully forecast for the current year-not just here, but worldwide. People looking at the regions of Australia and unemployment figures see a two per cent shift per month, 4,000 or 5,000, and, notionally, movements of up to 20,000 bodies. It is just absolutely ludicrous. It creates uncertainty and it destabilises. The shift in regionalism is a follow-through of what the government has been doing now for some time. The devolution of departments-DEET and Social Security-has been substantial. In fact, in regional Australia now we have local autonomy and local management and, hence, local understanding and local purchasing are all fundamentally important. This budget also· proposes a massive cultural change-which is the idea of DSSwith Social Security, Employment, Education and Training and CSS cooperating in joint programs looking at ways in which the department that services the unemployed with financial support and the department which tries to help with training and finding work for them, work together to be innovative with new programs to try to maximise their understanding and support. I think that is only possible within the concept of the regional government perspective. This government is to be applauded, as is this budget, for finally recognising that we have upgraded in those ways. As I said, the national economy is in fact a series of regional economies clumped together. Statistics need to be completely revised structurally because they do not reflect the nation. The budget forecasting problems on the we have experienced-even though the Treasury has done better than the private forecasters-indicates that the level of forecasting we have seen in the last five years is not good enough, .nor is it good enough anywhere in the world. The way to solve it in Australia is to start analysing and doing the figures more on a regional basis than a state basis. Those opposite who want to doomsay this budget do themselves and the people of this country no justice. For those who are interested in these matters, this budget has much to recommend it. Debate (on motion by Dr Kemp) adjourned. NA Motion (by Mr Kerr) proposed: That the House do now adjourn Budget 1993-94

Speaker: Mr EVANS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: As one of the many community based initiatives I have commenced in the Cowan electorate, I have extended an invitation to all residents, no matter what their political persuasions, to write to me about issues and concerns they would like me to raise in federal parliament. Because parliament is meant to be the people's place, I am going to use this opportunity to air the concerns and frustrations of one of Australia's many struggling and confused citizens. Donna Matthews, a local resident of Morley, has taken up the challenge. I am confident that the concerns of Donna Matthews are echoed throughout the electorate of Cowan and across this· great nation. Ms Matthews writes: I have always been a Labor voter or supporter. My father was a stout Labor man and instilled the theory "Labor looks after the working class". So what happened? I had always believed that politicians had a "grand plan"a better understanding of how things should be run and what was best for the people, but now I'm a disillusioned voter and a very disillusioned labor voter. I do not intend to vote labor again while Mr Keating is leader, or even if he is replaced. Labor will have to get itself 'back on track' before I would give them my vote. The last budget has made me very angry. It is unfair, illegal and makes no sense in several areas. Where are the initiatives, where is the hope of work for me or my family? There's not a lot of difference between Dr Hewson's O.S.T and what Mr Keating has given us-except Dr Hewson was honest enough to tell us what he was going to do. Some of the sillier things in the budget are: 1. The petrol tax. I bought petrol on the Monday at approximately 61 cents a litre and on Wednesday it was 73.7 cents. OK. The increase was at midnight, but a whole 12 cents a litre? The petrol stations had fuel in their tanks bought at the cheaper price, so who gets the extra profit? Why isn't this called profiteering? This tax (as with others) is not even law yet. How is it that it can be charged? Does that mean someone can be arrested for something that will be passed as law in the next month? How do you intend to refund the extra money collected if bills aren't passed, and what about the paper work. What a waste of time; money and effort. 2. Cigarette tax This tax, as with all taxes, is about raising money. To make it look good we can say it will make people stop smoking and therefore save money in doctors or hospital bills (ie Medicare). Well, know we can make figures say anything. Add this, take that, adjust something else. Those people who do give up smoking, good, but how do you make up the money you would have received from them? Why do you target the smokers? Why not the drinkers, even more so? The amount of money drinkers and their families cost us as a society far outweighs what smokers cost. For example, who ever heard of a wife or kids being bashed because the husband smoked? How many car accidents are caused because the driver is a smoker? How many couples divorce over smoking? Consider the legal aid, the qmnselling, the court costs, not tp mention doctors and hospital costs, and its millions and millions of dollars. Who are the brewery owners that receive such good treatment? What about Austudy? Why is that being given to the parents, but at a lesser amount?· And the dependent spouse rebate. Why change this? It's still the same for single income families with no children, but single income families with children get a home child care allowance of approximately the same value. Will this be taxed? What do these changes achieve apart from costing a fortune. Imagine all the letters and postage costs for informing Austudy receivers. The mountains of paper work and confusion will.overtake any savings in seconds. Why can't Labor ministers think like a normal person-it is stupid to waste money on unnecessary changes. People who work pay taxes. Build an industry here, not give everything away overseas, encourage people to work, build recycling plants, give us some incentive to save. I could write about many more things but I've covered some of my concerns. I don't normally put pen to paper or even voice my complaints but I've had enough-the government needs to know that a lot of the people are unhappy with what is happening. Donna Matthews of Morley, a true believer, does not need me to comment further, other than to say thank you. Chile

Speaker: Mr TANNER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Melbourne) (11.25 p.m.)In view of the forthcoming visit of President Patricio Aylwin from Chile, I wish to make a few comments on the current situation in that country. In post-dictatorial times in Chile, whilst some progress has been made towards we all the achievement of true democracy, which has been positively acknowledged in the international community, very serious concerns remain in relation to human rights. Since 1990 some 200 political prisoners have been detained in prisons such as the Penitencieria, Santo Domingo women's prison, San Miguel and Concepcion City, Rancagua .. Amnesty International reports as recently as March 1993 con finn torture and ill-treatment by members of the security forces. Carabineros, the unifonned police, is the force most frequently mentioned in these accusations, although cases of torture by members of the Policia de Investigacioines de Chile, criminal investigations police, have also been reported. The methods of torture mentioned in these reports by Amnesty International include beatings of the whole body, sometimes using fireanns and other objects, punching and kicking, near asphyxiation using plastic bags over the head, electric shocks, deprivation of sleep and food, and the use of blindfolds. The victims of torture referred to in the Amnesty International report are individuals accused of politically motivated offences. There are also a number of people who seem to have been victims of apparently random acts of violence by members of the security forces. By way of example, I would like to quote fairly briefly from the 1993 Amnesty International report. Christian Cardenas Jofre was detained in the street on 9 March 1992 by members of the Investigacioines de Chile and taken to their headquarters in Santiago where he was held until 12 March. Reports stated: Christian Cardenas was beaten, punched and kicked all over his body, received blows to the ears, a torture method known as 'the telephone' and had electric shocks applied to various parts of his A torture complaint was submitted to the third criminal court in Santiago on 20 March. To Amnesty International's knowledge he still remains in prison. At this point, I would like to acknowledge the presence in the gallery this evening of members of the Chilean Human Rights Committee, Mr Renaldo Torres, Mr Manuel Flores and Mr Alex Aqueveque, who have supplied me with this report. Most cases of human rights violations committed after the period covered by the 1978 amnesty law in Chile remain unresolved. I recognise the many obstacles faced by the Chilean government in addressing the legacy of past human rights violations but I believe that the government has the continuing obligation to ensure that, firstly, full investigations into human rights abuses under the Pinochet regime, including all complaints of torture, are carried out in order that the full truth is made known and that those responsible are brought to justice; secondly, the proceedings against prisoners charged with politically motivated offences are re-examined without delay, in order to detennine whether those prisoners who did not receive a fair trial according to international standards should be released or should have their case reheard under fair procedures; thirdly, any allegations of torture, or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment should be immediately and impartially investigated and those responsible brought to justice; and, finally, immediate action should be taken with respect to the 1991 Rettig report which establishes that there are still some 2,025 missing or disappeared persons, many of whom are women and children, in Chile. In conclusion, the government of Australia should continue to explore, as it is doing, all avenues of increased trade and commerce with Chile as well as other countries in the Latin American region. It also has an obligation to take advantage of the opportunity of President Aylwin's visit to. convey that, in accordance with our general standards with respect to human rights in this country, the examples of torture as presented in the Amnesty International report and the recent killings of two peaceful demonstrators on 11 September who were marking the 20th annibody. versary of the coup against President Allende, as reported in the Age, and the fact that General Pinochet, who is responsible for the killing of the thousands of Chileans whilst in power still remains in control of the Chilean anned forceS, confinn that today many lives in Chile are under threat and that democracy, fragile as it is, still remains very much under threat in that country. Parker, Miss Evelyn Helena: Death

Speaker: Mr CAMERON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I would like to bring to the notice of the House the passing of a great Australian-more particularly, a great Western Australian. In the early hours of this morning, Miss Evelyn' Helena Parker DBE, JP, died in Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital at the age of 85 .. From 1953 to 1975, Miss Parker was a councillor with the Subiaco City Council and made history by becoming our first lady mayor from 1975 to 1978. In all, she served 25 years in local government. In her professional career, Miss Parker worked as it school teacher around country areas of Western Australia and later in metropolitan Perth. Ev Parker was a feminist in the true senseof the word; by her words and actions, she forwarded the cause of women in a manner matched by very few of her peers. I first got to know her when, I married her niece, Wendy, 22 years ago. When the new Subiaco City Public Library was named after Aunty Ev in more recent years, she confided in me, 'I haven't made a public speech in many years.' What shall I say?'. I suggested she should say that she was delighted to be able to name the Evelyn H. Parker Library before it became the Evelyn H. Parker Memorial Library. This rather tickled her fancy and it was particularly wellreceived by the crowd on the day; I can , assuteyou. Evelyn Parker will ,pe re1llembered with great fondness by many the:>usands. of Western Australians who were fortunate enough to have her as their tea.cher. To the very end, remained passionately interested in. education and politics. A sta-nch defen<;l-r of loc.al goveflllIlent from party political inter(erence, she was a great encouragement to me when I discussed with her my political ambition over a number of years. Because of her declining health, she was unable to attend the election night function at the Yokine Recreation Centre 'on 13 March this year. So, after the polls closed, with my family, I visited Aunty Ev at her retirement home in Joondanna. When' it became clear, early in the evening, that I had enjoyed a: comfortable victory in the electorate of Stirling, the only person moreexc,ited than me was Aunty Ev. Despite heaith problems, she remained keenly interested in politics right up until death this morning. When we called into the hospital to say goodbye last Saturday-knowing that perhaps that was the last time that we would speak to her before travelling to Canberra-her first questions were of the family and Canberra.' . Ev Parker will be sorely. missed by her colleagues from the associations df which she has been a valued member, by her former pupils, by her former fellow councillors of the city of Subiaco in Western Australia, by her very many friends, and by her surviving brothers-James, John and Forbes-and their families. After a rich and full public and private life, during which Evelyn Helena Parker contributed so much, may she rest in peace. Fishing: Threatened Species Mrs SI;LVIA SMITH (Bass) (11.33 p.m.) - I draw to. the House's attention a case of unseen devastation - hat is occurring, and has been occurring over recent years, in the southern waters of Australia off the coast of Tasmania. It has been brought to my attention recently that a rare species is being overfished in TasII:1anian wl;lters. This is the Tasmanian sea dragon and.it now faces extinction as a direct result of insidious, indulgent overfishing in the waters off the south-eastern coast of Tasmania. " This warning was given last week by the threatened species network. It has called on she the federal government, via the Minister for the Environment, Sport, and Territories (Mrs Kelly);to stop this malicious exploitation of the multicoloured sea dragon, phylloteryx taeniolatus. These. beautiful creatures, which grow to about 45 centimetres, are being exported alive for aquarium markets in Asia and North ,America to satisfy a minute, indulgent market to the detriment of the sea dragon. Furthermore, there is the supposition that the sea dragon has.aphrodisiac properties when dried and crushed. This idea has created a demand in Asia and is depleting the species at an alarming rate. Phylloteryx taeniolatus is naturally a very rare species. Its distinct biology makes it highly susceptible to extinction. 'Therefore, her fishing from the wild must not be allowed to  ened species network coordinator in an interview with the Launceston Examiner newspaper last· week. The Tasmanian division of sea fisheries is considering a ban on the taking of rare species such, as this weed dwelling sea dragon. But, more importantly, we need' a national ban to stop exports of all rare 'species of sea dragons. This includes sea horses and the pipe fish. These species are intimately fragile dwellers in our ecology and far too vulnerable to. justify this crazy exploitation for utterly fnvolous purposes. If those persons in Asia must, partake of these quaint remedies, they should be compelled' to breed the species in captivity, otherwise yet another rare and beautiful species will disappear from the face of the earth. Tasmanian divers have reported that the sea dragon population in Tasmania's south-east has been almost completely depleted in recent years .. Advertisements in national fishing magazmes are offering top rates. National intervention is necessary to ban the export of t-e .sea dragon, phylloteryx taeniolatus, pIus Similar species. In conclusion, I request that action be taken now before' it is too late. Taxation: Wine

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: This e-ening I want to exercise my democratic nght to speak on the budget deficit reduction bills that were put through the House in a hurry tonight under guillotine by the governmeot. In particular, I refer to the Sales Tax (Customs) (Deficit Reduction) Bill which contained the increased sales tax on wine. We have seen the government rush this bill through the House of Representatives this evening. It has done away with the rights of a lot of the people of Australia to' have representatives speak on the issue in'this House in the proper manner. I find that I have to speak in this adjournment debate when I will get only five minutes to talk about this very important issue. In the electorate of Lyne there exists a number of quality boutique wineries which, through hard work and intelligent planning have been achieving phenomenal success. Thmost notable of these wineries is Cassegrain winery. Along with the Charley Brothers Winery, it provides much needed employment in the Port Macquarie area. The Cassegrain winery, producing some of the world's best quality wine-40 per cent of which is exported; mostly to Japan-relies enormously on the domestic market to achieve economies of scale, as is the case with the majority ohmall export companies. Domestic sales underpin those exports and domestic sales are extreme" ly price sensitive. This 55 per cent increase will wreak havoc on this local industry. The Cassegrains' conc:;em for their future is certainly not unfounded- If this tax is introduced, domestic sales are expected to drop by 31 million litres, with a corresponding drop in grape demand. Along with this, the Wine Makers Federation of Australia estimates a loss of export income of around $126 million per annum-surely something that Australia cannot afford. The recently released Sharp report clearly ,states that the competitive advantage of the Australian wine industry is neither as secure nor an strong as some would wish. It further states:, ' Any change in the tax system which reduces the ability of Australian wine exporters to invest in the building of market-based assets has the potential to substantially downgrade the industry's international competitive advantage. ' TheSe sales tax increas- will therefore place the Cassegrain family winery at adistirict disadvantage. The survival of the Cassegrains to date has only been because the members of their extended family work six days per week all year round at minimal wages. They recognise that they cannot keep this up forever and are currently trying to plan for their future. However, with the introduction of this sales tax on wines, along with all the other burdens their on business which thisgovemmen.t has introduced over the years, the future looks very bleak. This is. not scaremongering. A business decision to close the winery, may have to be taken as the only alternative. I will put on record some correspondence recently received from Mr Claude <;:::assegrain. It states: The impediments and the ·artificial costs that a business in pure competition has to endure are staggering. The anticipated 'effect of the additional sales tax on our product includes the possible closure of our viticulture enterprise: time will telL If Cassegrain closes, it would have an enormous impact on the community of Port Macquarie and Wauchope because the· winery plays a significant role in the tourism infrastructure of the whole region. As now seems to be the common trend with this government, the worse part of the sales tax on wine is that it is an uneven tax. Those who produce a quality product carry the largest burden and . pay a disproportionate amount of tax on each litre of wine produced and sold on the domestic market. This government does not realise that the quality producers are also the flag leaders for the export market I repeat: it is .domestic sales for these quality producers that underpin their exports. The recently released Sharp report was, for mine, thefitial hail in the coffin for the uneconomic plans of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) for the wine industry. The report clearly 'shows the Treasurer's 'Canberra is Australia, Australia is Canberra' opinion to be quite wrong. As Brian Croser has said: The gap between theory in Canberra and practice in the highly competitive international marketplace is unbelit(vably frustrating to this model industry. I have heard a lot of talk amongst those on the other side of politics that we on this side have turned into the opposers of everything. Why would we not oppose this measure? The government promised no tax increases and the people of Australia expect us to stand up on their behalf after they were blatantly lied to in the campaign for the 13 March election. The government has no mandate to increase this tax and the people of Australia will not forgive the government for it. I am astounded at the government's B-grade economics with regard to the sales tax on the wine industry. Does the government not recognise that the few large wineries, consisting of 70 to 80 per cent of the market, have their costs of production artificially subsidised by the many small individual wineries? Speaker: Mr WAKELIN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I want to make a few observations about the recent draft report, Impediments to regional industry adjustment. It is very appropriate that I do. so because I come from one of the largest electorl\tes in the country.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Ninety-two per cent of South Australia.

Speaker: Mr WAKELIN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: As the honourable member for Fisher says, my electorate covers 92 per cent of South Australia. For many generations the region has been subjected to a dominant urban culture, and this report's coming to light is most welcome. The report looks at regional labour costs-and we could be excused for believing, from the headlines of recent days, that this was all that was in the report. That is my main motivation for speaking to it tonight. I say to Mr Kelty, and it is documented very well on page 51,'that there is already regional wage variation. I think it is very important to recognise that. The report talks about labour retraining, labour and capital adjustment, services and regional industry adjustment, the infrastructure, regional ramifications of financial relations between governments, adjustment assistance, and the regional dimension. The report discusses the actual policies. During midto late-October members of the Industry Commission will be taking evidence around Australia. At the public hearings people will have an opportunity to comment on this document, and I hope people will take every opportunity .to do that. If I were to comment on a weakness in this document, I would say that perhaps there is nothing on the indirect tax burden-and this is somewhat ironic, having listened to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), and bearing in mind the general malaise of the budget. I am on' the public record as saying that fuel excise is one of the most unjust taxes on regional Australia. It is not just a matter of the 20c or 30c a litre that is imposed; it is the whole structure and the way it impacts on the cost of productionright through the whole chain.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: We would have scrapped it.

Speaker: Mr WAKELIN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Quite right. It would have been gone by now if we had our opportunity; but that is another story. It is with great pleasure that I have looked at the document. There are over 250 pages and I have not had the opportunity to look at it all, but it is a most welcome document and I thank the commissioners for the effort that they have put in. I commend the document to Mr Kelty and others, and they might have a look at it in its full context, In conclusion, I will quote from the document and perhaps try to sum up some of the aspirations of those people who have already made submissions. The quote, I think .from the Geraldton development board in Western Australia, states: Unless all levels of gO\1emment act to provide incentives to get people back into the country, many rural towns are in danger of closing; simply existing to house a large ployed people ... Federal and S-te govemmenhave the means to encourage the development of 'rural and regional communities through public sector employment policies, supply of physical social infrastructure and economic incentives. That is the key to regional Australia. I hope , These ,are debts for fanns that this parliament may take some notice it. ' Macquarie Rural Advisory Service

Speaker: Mr COBB
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: U\st week I attended the annual meeting of the Macquarie Rural Advisory Service in Dubbo. This rural counselling group, which covers fanning districts of Narromine, Dubbo and Wellington, has been operating for two years. Like other groups, around Australia, it funded 25 per cent by the local community, 25 per cent by the state government and 50 per cent by the federal government. It is run by a board of 16 volunteers, the president which is the very capable Trevor Stevenson. The rural counsellor there, Kathy Sims, is very highly regarded throughout the district. She has 15 per cent of the fanners' of those three areas on her books. A fair guess is that half or more of those will eventually go into unless there is a big upturn in the rural indusold try before long. Listening to the presentation of her annual report the other night and to contributions of the other members at the meeting, some very disturbing trends came through. Most of us here will be familiar the run-of-the-mill causes of fanners' difficulthe ties: low commodity prices, high costs, droughts, wet harvests and, in particular, high interest rates that prevlliled for so long in the 1980s. , Mr SLIPPER - And the Labor government.

Speaker: Mr COBB
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: That was caused by the Labor government. Many of the fanners in trouble bought extra land, attempting to become more efficient, and got caught by these high, interest rates. Those going out of the industry through poor management account for quite a small proportion of fanners-contrary to popular belief. It is indeed sad that ,agriculture is losing some of its better operators. The largely untold story is that of the tremendous stress put on fanning families which is lead'or ,ing to break-ups of families and, in some body pf unemcases, suicides. I learnt the other night that the fanners on the books of the Macquarie Rural Advisory and Service have an average debt of $316,000, which is up by $19,000 on last year's figure. 9f an average size of of 2,000 hectares. The average asset of those fanns amounts to about thiee-quarters of a million dollars, though the great bulk of them have assets of less than $400,000. Over the last year there has been a trend whereby we have an increase in the debt level the of $19,000. Carry over finance is becoming very hard to access; the criteria for getting it have tightened considerably. The creditors are is applying increased pressure. They are now asking 'for three-monthly reports. They are putting flow charts together. They want five year histories and three-year projections. This of is very time consuming, quite costly to put together and involves a lot of guesswork. It is causing a backlog for appointments with Kathy, the rural counsellor. She is already working a 50-hour week. ' On top of this most farmers are still locked high interest rates,.' Many are still on the five-year loans which will not expire until the end of next year. They are paying 17 and the 18 per cent. But even those who are accessing loans today are, paying 91f2 per cent prime rates from the bank, to which is added two to with four per cent for faim margins. That brings figure up to 111/2 per cent; when an extra one or two percent in bank charges and fees the is tacked on to that, 13 and 14 per cent interest rates are commonly paid. This is at a time when inflation is running at one per cent. I think it is a disgrace. ' Many farmers are in trouble. They cannot just lock into· the present low rates, as some people seem to be saying they can. These days, banks are giving farmers only one-year loans. The high value farms in the more fertile areas are getting into the most trouble. Farms in the cheaper land areas are often in a better position. Surprisingly to me, there is a strong drift towards farmers in trouble with very high equity levels, because they cannot get carry-on finance. Four per cent of the clients on Kathy's books have equity levels of 90 to 100 per cent; over 10 per cent have equity levels between 80 and 90 per cent; and 17 per cent have equity levels between 70 and 80 per cent. More than 30 per cent of her clients have equity levels greater than 70 per cent. That can be compared with the bottom level, those with equity levels between 0 and 30 per cent, which accounts for just over 10 per cent of her clients. In conclusion, the workload per client has increased dramatically over the last year. Bank pressures on these clients are becoming intolerable. The farmers in better positions are falling into trouble. She is getting more clients on the books. The projection in the budget papers that $4 million in funding will come down to $2 million next year is totally unrealistic. The need next year will be greater, not less. Furthermore, RAS funding is projected to come down from $150 million to somewhere around $50 million, to be made upout of state reserves. That is also unrealistic. Taxation: Credit Unions

Speaker: Ms WORTH
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Mr Speaker, I commend the Senate for voting today to support Senator Hill's motion to refer the provisions of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.1) 1993 concerning the taxation treatment of credit unions to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. The inquiry must report on or before 18 October and will be required to examine: (a) the role played by credit unions in Australia; (b) their structure, operations and community services; (c) the reasons for credit unions being granted a partial tax exemption in 1974; Cd) the effect of the taxation treatment proposed by the government on credit unions' capital formation and on their continued provision of financial and community services; (e) the effect of the ta-ation treatment proposed by the government on asset concentration in both the credit union movement and retail financial sector, and the implications of this effect upon consumer choice; and Cf) whether the reasons for the differentiated tax treatment of credit unions and building societies are still valid. Credit unions will now be given the opportunity to present their case in support of credit unions retaining their tax exempt status on income earned from loans to members. Credit unions are financial cooperatives owned by their members and served by volunteer directors. Credit unions are non-profit organisations, and any surplus funds are used to meet capital requirements, as required by legislation, with the remainder invested to improve member services and to maintain credit unions' traditional low interest on loans and low fees policy. The reinvestment by credit unions of surplus funds pays for community services, such as financial counselling, and member services, such as free bill paying and free payroll deductions. As with all other financial institutions, credit unions do pay income tax on all areas of their business. Only earnings from loans to members are exempt-a measure that was introduced by the Whitlam government 20 years ago in recognition of the role of credit unions in providing lower cost personalloails to Australians who did not have access to bank finance. The removal of the tax exemption will seriously erode the ability of credit unions to maintain services and member benefits at current levels. It will jeopardise the position of credit unions as virtually the only source of low cost personal loan finance for many thousands of South Australians. The tax will cost South Australian credit unions an estimated $35 million over a five-year period. Regional Aquatic Centre: Bendigo

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) today acknowledged that all of Australia should participate Sydney Olympic Games. 1 thank her for that statement. 1 concur totally, adding only that her comment should apply particularly to rural Australians. . In 1956 1 had the privilege and honour of carrying the Olympic torch. I ask the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) at the table to take of my request of the minister for sport. 1 want her to make good her support for a project that has the support of the Bendigo Regional Recreation Board, the five municipalities surrounding Bendigo, the Bendigo YMCA, the user groups, the Victorian state government-which has put in $500,OOO-and the whole community by providing financial assistance of $250,000 for the construction of a regional aquatic centre. This would enable Bendigo and district to produce another Olympic gold and bronze swimmer like Faith Leech from Bendigo in 1956. 1 believe there are a lot of opportunities throughout regional Australia for the government to show its goodwill. I ask the minister at the table to take up this particular matter with the minister for sport. Bell, Mr John: Death

Speaker: Mr RONALDSON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise tonight with a great degree of sadness to mourn the loss of a great Australian. I am sure that the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr), who is at the table, would be aware of the work of the late John Bell, the founder of the Esprit clothing company. Tragically, Mr Bell was found dead at his home in Melbourne yesterday morning. On behalf of both sides of this House, 1 would like to pay tribute to this very great Australian. He was a passionate supporter of Australian youth, a passionate environmentalist and a passionate fighter for Australia's homeless young people. He had an enormous love for rural Australia and he was very proud of his roots. He was raised in country Western Australia. Last Thursday night in Ballarat he spoke passionately about his upbringing and what that had taught him. The great thing about Mr Bell was that he pricked the corporate conscience. He was a man who did it on his own. He established the Esprit Cares Trust Fund, which generated in the an enormous amount of money which was going to Australia's youth. I believe that he single-handedly raised youth issues and the problems confronting the young people of Australia in the corporate sector and it was an extraordinary success. 1 was on the board of the Open Family note Foundation with Mr Bell. Mr Speaker, in the short period that I have known him, I thought that his drive was extraordinary, as was his commitment to the young people that you and 1 so passionately care about, as does everyone in this chamber and all our colleagues. He was their· great fighter and they have lost a very close friend. Mr Bell was chairman of the Victorian state government's council of youth affairs. He was involved in the Life, Be in It campaign and in the big brothers, big sisters program. His whole life and the many hours he worked every day were committed to others. 1 think he showed-it was a great lesson to all corporate . Australia-that there are many things to life; there is the development of business but 1 think primarily there is the development of Australia, particularly Australian youth. I am deeply saddened by the loss of Mr Bell. 1 do not think that he would have wanted to have been considered irreplaceable but it will be a quite extraordinary person who will take up the work of the late John Bell. Question resolved in the affirmative. The following answers to questions were circulated: Convention on the Settlement of Investment Di-putes (Question No- 79) Mr Melham asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 May 1993: (1) Did the Whitlam Government sign the 1975 Convention on the Settlement of Investment Disputes between States and Nationals of Other States on 24 March 1975. (2) Did the Hawke Government deposit the instrument of ratification on 2 May 1991; if so, did it designate both mainland Territories and all States exc-pt Western Australia for the purposes of Article 25(1) of the Convention. (3) When the Fraser Government consulted Western Australia in 1976 and 1978 did the Government of Charles Court express a preference for not being designated fQr the purposes of Article 25(1). (4) When the Hawke Government consulted Western Australia in 1984 and 1991 did the Burke and Lawrence Governments, respectively, confirm the Court Government's preference. (5) Which States have deposited instruments of ratification since the answer to question No. 1752 (Hansard, 15 October 1992, page 2355). (6) Has the Keating Government pursued the question of designation of Western Australia with the Government of Richard Court; if so, with what outcome.

Speaker: Mr LAVARCH
Title: NOTICES
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Yes. However, the Convention was adopted on 18 March 1965, not 1975 as stated in the question. (2) Yes, Australia deposited the instrument of ratification on 2 May 1991 and designated both mainland. Territories and all States except Western Australia as constituent subdivisions for the purposes of Article 25(1). (3) Yes. I am advised that on 13 April 1976 the then Prime Minister, Me Fraser, wrote to each of the Premiers seeking comments on the draft Bill authorising ratification by Australia of the Convention. Sir Charles Court, the then Premier of WestNA em Australia, replied by letter of 10 June 1976 stating that he did not favour ratification of the Convention by Australia and requesting that, should the Commonwealth decide to ratify, Western Australia not be designated as a constituent subdivision under Article 25(1) of the Convention. On 25 September 1978, Mr Fraser, the then Prime Minister, wrote again to Sir Charles Court and asked him to reconsider his position on the matter. The then Acting Premier of Western Australia responded, affirming the State's earlier position. (4) Yes. I am advised that on 4 June 1984, the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke wrote to Me Burke, then Premier of Western Australia, advising him that Australia intended to ratify the Convention at an early date and expressing a hope that Western Australia would be willing to join all other States of the Commonwealth and the Northem Territory in being designated a "constituent subdivision" for the purposes of the Convention. In a reply dated 31 August 1984, Mr Burke advised that the Western Australian position on designation had not changed. I am advised that the then Prime Minister, Me Hawke, wrote in some detail to the then Premier of Western Australia, Dr Lawrence, on 23 October 1990, outlining the benefits of designation and asking that Western Australia reconsider its position on the question of designation under Article 25(1). In a reply dated 22· February 1991, Dr Lawrence advised that Western Australia remained opposed to ratification of the Convention and requested that, if ratification occurred, Western Australia not be designated under Article 25(1). In response, on 16 April 1991, Me Hawke wrote to Dr Lawrence agreeing to her request but regretting the Western Australian Government's inability to give favourable consideration to designation. (5) The Attorney-General's Department has corresponded with the International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) and ICSID has provided the Department with a list of contracting states and signatories of the Convention as at 18 May 1993. I am advised that, since the list provided in answer to question 1752, the following five countries have lodged instruments of ratification; Armenia, Azerbaijan, China, Georgia and Turkmenistan. The Czech Republic has also deposited an instrument of ratification; the Czech and Slovak Federal Republic had previously been a contracting state. The list of the 107 parties to the Convention, together with the date of entry into force for each country, has been forwarded to the honourable member. (6) In view of the fact that, over a 15 year period up to 1991, Western Australia consistently requested that it not be designated, the question has not been raised with the new Western Australian Government. In his letter in 1991, the former Prime Minister indicated that, should the Western Australian Government change its position on this matter, the appropriate designation could' take place. ' Mr Tickner-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: ATSIC does not hold the information requested by the honourable member. There are more than twenty separate Aboriginal Legal Services which receive funding from ATSIC to provide legal services to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in their respective communities .. The Legal Services operate as autonomous bodies and develop their own guidelines and practices for providing legal assistance according to their assessment of the needs of their clients. Arising from this autonomy there is a range of methods used by Aboriginal Legal Services to collect data on assistance provided in civil, nal, family and corporate law matters. An assessment of the funding basis of Aboriginal Legal Services in 1992 found that the vast majority of matters handled by the Aboriginal Legal Services involved representation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people charged with criminal offences. However, at present there is no standardised fonnat of data collection nal Legal Services. The May 1992 assessment by ATSIC developed a series of recommendations, one of which was for the establishment of a national, computerised, statistical data system to enable priorities to be determined based on demonstrated need. (4) Did the fortner Prime Minister assure the International Labour Conference in Geneva on 10 June 1983 that (a) Australia's ratification of Convention No. 151-Labour Relations (Public Service), 1978 should occur before the end of 1983 and (b) his Government had committed itself to ratifying Convention No. 155-0ccupational Safety and Health, 1981 as a matter of course. (5) What progress has been made in ratifying the two conventions referred to in part (4).

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: SIGNATURE RATIFICATION VENTION
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) RATIFICATION OF CONVENTIONS Since 15 September 1992, Australia has ratified the following International Labour Organisation Conventions: Convention No. 135, Workers'Representatives, 1971, ratified on 26 February 1993 Convention No. 158, Termination of Employment, 1982, ratified on 26 February 1993. FEDERAL-STATE CONSULTATIONS The answer to question No.1805 provided information on consultations with the States and Territories by the Task Force established by the Government to review the ratification prospects of ILO Conventions. The unratified Conventions under consideration by the Task Force have not changed since the answer to that question, except that the ratification of Conventions No. 135 and 158 has removed them from consideration. REPORTS TO THE DIRECTOR-GENERAL In accordance with Article 22 of the ILO Constitution, Australia reported to the Director-General in 1992 on the effect given to the following 14 Conventions which Australia has ratified: . ILO Convention No 7, Minimum Age (Sea), 1920; ILO Convention No 9, Placing of Seamen, 1920; ILO Convention No 11, Right of Association (Agriculture), 1921; ILO Convention No 47, Forty-Hour Week, 1935; ILO Convention No 87, Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise, 1948; ILO Convention No 99, Minimum Wage Fixing Machinery (Agriculture), 1951; ILO Convention No 111, Discrimination (Employment and Occupation), 1958; ILO Convention No 112, Minimum Age (Fishermen), 1959; , ILO Convention No 122, Employment Policy, 1964; ILO Convention No 131, Minimum Wage Fixing, 1970; ILO Convention No 137, Dock Work, 1973; ILO Convention No 144, Tripartite Consultation (International Labour Standards), 1976; ILO Convention No 156, Workers with Family Responsibilities, 1981; and ILO Convention No 159, Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (Disabled Persons), 1983. Reports under Article 22 on Conventions Nos 11, 47, 87, 112 and 122 were also prepared by the Australian Government in conjunction with the Territory of Norfolk Island. In accordance with Article 19 of the ILO Constitution, Australia was also due to report to the Director-General in 1992 on the effect which had been given to Recommendation No. 165, Workers with Family Responsibilities, which supplements Convention No 156, Workers with Family Responsibilities, 1981. By arrangement with the ILO, this report was combined with the Article 22 report on that Convention. (2) Yes. (3) The Government appreciates the significance of 1993 as the International Year of the World's Indigenous People. At the same time, the Government recognises the need for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to be involved in considering 'ratification of this Convention, in light of its significance for issues affecting them. Consultations with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and organisations are being conducted by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in order to assist the Government in its consideration of the ratification of the Convention. (4) (a) Yes. (b) Yes. (5) The Government remains committed to pursuing the ratification of appropriate international conventions, particularly those which protect important rights. This commitment motivated the establishment in 1991 of the Task Force, referred to in (1), to review and accelerate Australian ratification of ILO Conventions. An important part of the process of pursuing the ratification of international conventions involves consulting the States and Territories. Both Convention No. 151 and Convention No. 155 have been the subject of consultations with State and Territory Governments, at Ministerial and officer level, in accordance with the normal arrangements for proposed ratification of ILO Conventions. They have also been the subject of discussions by the Task Force with State and Territory representatives. A majority of States have agreed to ratification. Both Conventions have been identified as suitable targets for ratification in the Third Report of the Task Force. The Government hopes soon to be in a position to make a decision on ratification of these Conventions. Funds should not be made available to research questions relating to sovereignty. (b) Funds may be made available for the employment of experts to establish anthropological, archaeological, historical and, other evidence relevant to the making of a land claim under common law. , (c), Depending on the total amount of funds available, and the availability sources, funds may be provided for litigation of a common law land claim, where the delegate is satisfied that there is'areasonable chance of the claim succeeding, and those other avenues for satisfying the claim are not available. In making a decision, the delegate shall have regard to the feasibility of a negotiated settlement of the claim. , (d) Funds will not normally be provided direct to a priyate legal fiim. Funds may be provided to an Aboriginal Legal Service (ALS), acting on behalf of A-original Claimants, if the ALS can demonstrate capacity and competence in pursuing test cases. A private legal firm may be contracted out by a funded Aboriginal organisation to carry out the necessary specialist work. (e) Priority will be given to the provision of funds for researching and/or litigating common law land claims where there is urgency because of the age of those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander custodians who are able to provide evidence to document land claims. (f) Funds may be made available for the holding of conferences to allow Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities to explore opportunities for land claims under common law. A ceiling of $25,000 should apply for each conference, unless exceptional circumstances exist.
